Modify Core Unit Budget, ORA-001 (Oracle Gas Costs) Summary: This requests 8,771,477.05 DAI. The breakdown is as follows: Oracle Gas Costs (1/1/22-3/31/22): 3,932,547.84 Oracle Emergency Fund: 1,805,407.21 Maker Foundation Refund (~8/1/21-12/31/21): 3,033,522 Recommendation: Vote Abstain. The costs for ongoing and future oracle gas costs should be in a separate proposal from a 3 million DAI transfer to the Maker Foundation, which requires more discussion. It is not clear why a nonprofit foundation that existed to bootstrap MakerDAO is now sending a bill for 3 million DAI. That being said, this 3 million DAI is bundled together with a “must pass” proposal. We prefer to pick our battles, and while this is disappointing, this is not a hill we plan to die upon. Onboarding Tech-Ops Core Unit (TECH-001) Summary: This would onboard the proposed Tech-Ops CU. The annualized budget requested is just around 2.5m DAI (NB: There is a discrepancy in the proposal where not all numbers were updated to a slight decrease in budget, and this does not appear to be reflected in the poll; the discrepancy is just under 80k DAI). MKR per full time contributor is budgeted at 75.68 per year. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The budget is a bit high, but after sharing that view, the proposed facilitator was able to find a way to lower the budget. It still seems expensive on the MKR side, but the personnel have performed good work to date and were willing to compromise. That’s a solid combination. Onboarding Strategic Finance Core Unit (SF-001) Summary: This would onboard the proposed Strategic Finance CU. Its mission would primarily be a dual mandate to provide and improve financial reporting within the DAO, and allocate capital to improve efficiency. The annualized budget requested is approximately 990k DAI. MKR per full time contributor is budgeted at 80 per year. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The facilitator and other staff are members from the Real World Finance (RWF) CU, and are experienced and knowledgeable about MakerDAO’s internal workings. The facilitator, @Aes, has been a driving force for greater internal cost controls and financial oversight. The other prong of the SF mandate that is capital efficiency is also supported by GFX – which has two proposals that are in part to address that lack of efficiency. Aes and @SebVentures will be addressing a largely unmet need for the DAO. MIP62: Collateral Offboarding Process Summary: Provide a standard procedure for notifying users of collateral offboarding. Recommendation: Vote Yes. GFX made this proposal, and collaborated with members from GovAlpha, CES, and GovComms in drafting it. This will likely need further updates, but will support @collateral-core-unit in their mission to have a “lifecycle” approach to collateral management. Modify Core Unit Budget, SNE-001 Summary: This is a budget for the StarkNet CU to pursue its Phase II of deliverables. The total budget is 974,583 DAI, of which StarkNet will cover half. The total request is for 487,292 DAI. Recomendation: Vote Yes. The StarkNet CU is inexpensive, and a way to continue pursuing L2 solutions beyond what Protocol Engineering CU can output. Hedging in as many directions at once as possible is prudent, and the continued cost sharing with StarkNet is appropriate and makes the expenses quite manageable. This tranche of deliverables include L2>L1 fast withdrawals and L2<>L2 teleportation with Maker Wormhole, adding to network effects of the former including Arbitrum and Optimism. MIP64: Ratification Poll for Bug Bounty Program for MakerDAO Critical Infrastructure Summary: Proposed by the Immunefi Security CU, this is establishes a bug bounty program managed by that core unit. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is necessary for the Immunefi CU to fulfill its mandate, and Immunefi has become one of the leaders in Web3 bug bounty management. MIP63: Maker Keeper Network Summary: This is a series of contracts to interface with third-party keepers in the MakerDAO ecosystem. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Supporting and otherwise encouraging functional and participating keepers in the various auction formats is important. While the keeper ecosystem is sufficient at the moment, any technical assistance to maintain the health of that ecosystem is critical to the overall health of the Maker protocol. Offboarding Content Production Core Unit (MKT-001) Summary: This is a proposal to reduce budget to 0 DAI and offboard the facilitator for Content CU. Recommendation: Vote No. While some improvements could be made in quality and quantity of deliverables, there is no replacement for this core unit available. Maker has no marketing core unit, and cannot afford to also have the Content CU go dark. There would be even less communication with external stakeholders and the public. Facilitator Onboarding for RWF-001 Summary: This proposal onboards Will Remor as RWF-001 facilitator. RWF CU currently has no facilitator after @SebVentures stepped down following a related proposal by @rune to offboard him. @williamr is the replacement to prevent the CU from being without a facilitator. Recommendation: Vote Yes. RWF needs a facilitator. Will has shown himself to be qualified and involved in RWF. The only concern is that Will has also been approved to work for Aave in a similar role – real world asset risk assessments. It would be useful to get some clarification from Will if he will work for a competing protocol as well as head the Maker RWF CU. GFX would support a commensurate increase in Will’s pay to ensure Maker has exclusive access to his services with regard to real world assets in DeFi. Modify Core Unit Budget, DUX-001 Summary: This proposal is primarily to improve the process of funds flows, disbursements, technical implementation, and standardization. Recommendation: Vote Yes. These changes seem appropriate, and automating a stream of payments to a CU wallet is better than lump sum payments from a standpoint of DAO control. Modify Core Unit Budget, SES-001 Summary: This proposal is a similar set of changes as that proposed to the implementation of the DUX-001 budget. It is primarily around technical details and improved internal control, automation, and disclosure. Recommendation: Vote Yes. More automation and adjustments to implementation will improve the oversight of governance.

Thanks GFX for the thoughtful points. I’ve set out some points to address them and give context on how we think the Maple proposal benefits MakerDAO in scaling DAI issuance and diversifying the base of assets. One of the core value props is the addition of corporate loans to the asset base supporting DAI issuance. This sounds a lot like creating a portfolio manager rather than lending against specific collateral.  This is lending against corporate receivables and future cash flows. This is a new vertical asset type for Maker which diversifies its entry into the real world lending space. It currently supports small-to-med business lending through Centrifuge and institutional lending is a natural adjacency.  Small or no junior tranche/co-investors  Maple can include credit enhancement via the staked reserve. This is a junior tranche of MPL and USDC which is held in reserve to provide a buffer against defaults. The appropriate level size of this reserve can be part of commercial discussions. It receives a portion of the interest yield to incentivize it so we expect reasonable appetite.  Unsecured/undercollateralized loans  Loans are undercollateralized because we have found that this offering is required to attract the most creditworthy borrowers in the space. The concern highlighted is with credit risk. Expected credit losses are a combination of the Probability of Default and the Loss Given Default. Maple addresses this at the probability of default level by targeting large institutional borrowers where the Delegate 1) thoroughly due diligences borrower financials and 2) Borrowers execute a Master Loan Agreement which gives the legal right to enforce (this would not need to be conducted by Maker, there is a Cayman Foundation set up which would perform this). The other mitigation here is sizing. Maker’s allocation to undercollateralized loans would start as a small portion of the overall DAI portfolio.  Pool Delegate would oversee the DAI investments without direct voting by MakerDAO is a third way in which this would be “deep space” for Maker  Key concern identified is the ability of the Delegate to deviate in its underwriting. The counter here is that it is not scalable for MakerDAO to underwrite every loan and hence in any basket approach, where Maker is funding a pool of loans, there would need to be underwriting delegation of sorts. The outcome that needs to be solved is avoiding deterioration or drift in credit underwriting. This could best be accomplished through sharing the Delegate’s credit policy and review of portfolio performance on a regular (quarterly) basis to give MakerDAO comfort that standards are maintained.

GFX Labs supported the current executive, which contains changes that were ratified last week. Detailed discussion of each point can be found up-thread from here. 2 Polls Closing Jan 20 Open Market Committee Proposal Summary: This proposal would enact the following parameter changes: -Decrease ETH-A stability fee from 2.75% to 2.50% -Decrease wstETH-A stability fee from 4.00% to 3.00% -Decrease Gelato UNI V3 DAI/USDC (0.01%) stability fee from 1.00% to 0.50%f -Decrease maximum debt ceiling of LINK-A from 140m to 100m DAI -Decrease maximum debt ceiling of YFI-A from 130m to 50m DAI -Decrease maximum debt ceiling of UNI-A from 50m to 25m DAI -Decrease UNI V2 UNI/ETH maximum debt ceiling from 20m to 5m DAI -Decrease GUSD-A debt ceiling from 5m to 0 DAI -Decrease AAVE D3M target borrow rate from 3.9% to 3.75% Recommendation: Vote Yes. The ETH stability fee decreases are in line with market conditions – the Peg Stability Modules have been filling up quickly, reflecting lower demand for vault leverage than demand for DAI. These small decreases will also help protect Maker’s market share of ETH as a collateral in DeFi markets. The decrease in the Gelato DAI/USDC is also appropriate, as that collateral can serve as a small substitute for some PSM inflows. The debt ceiling decreases are appropriate given the lower liquidity recently for those collaterals, which increases risk of slippage in liquidation. The decrease of the GUSD-A debt ceiling is appropriate as a first step towards transitioning GUSD exposure to the new (and as yet unused) GUSD-PSM. The decrease in targeted borrow rate is appropriate given the parallel reduction in ETH-A stability fees. In the future, we would still like to see something other than rate targets as the metric by which D3M exposure is managed. Decrease Gelato UNI V3 DAI/USDC (0.01%) Liquidation Ratio Summary: This proposal would lower the liquidation ratio of this collateral from 105% to 102%. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Given the underlying stable-stable pairing, and the need for the Gelato LPs to serve as alternatives to the USDC PSM, this seems appropriate. Note that liquidations have been and will continue to be disabled for this collateral type.
GFX Labs supported the current executive. These were changes that had been discussed upthread, for those interested in specific positions by GFX.

1 Polls Ending Feb 3 Open Market Committee Proposal Summary: This proposal would change the following parameters: Decrease ETH-A fees from 2.5% to 2.25% Decrease ETH-B fees from 6.5% to 4% Decrease wstETH fees from 3% to 2.5% Decrease WBTC-A fees from 4% to 3.75% Decrease WBTC-B fees from 7% to 5% Decrease WBTC-C fees from 1.5% to 0.75% Decrease UNI V2 DAI/ETH from 2% to 1% Decrease UNI V2 WBTC/ETH from 3% to 2% Decrease UNI V2 USDC/ETH from 2.5% to 1.5% Decrease G-UNI V3 DAI/USDC (0.01%) from 0.5% to 0.25% Decrease TUSD fee from 1% to 0% Decrease AAVE D3M target borrow rate from 3.75% to 3.5% Decrease G-UNI V3 DAI/USDC (0.05%) debt ceiling from 500m to 100m DAI Increase G-UNI V3 DAI/USDC (0.01%) debt ceiling from 500m to 750m DAI Increase G-UNI V3 DAI/USDC (0.01%) gap from 10m to 50m DAI Recommendation: Vote Yes. At the margin, these lower rates may increase DAI borrowing. It would be nice to give this committee a grant or mandate to estimate borrower sensitivity to rates, though. Decreasing the TUSD fee is part of the offboarding housekeeping that will need to occur if fully offboarded. The D3M target rate is simply following the ETH-A rate decrease, having originally been pegged arbitrarily to the kink in the Aave borrowing curve. The rebalancing of the two G-UNI vault types makes sense given the migration to the 1 bps pool.
GFX Labs supported the current executive. Changes were largely around budgets and officially offboarding the Content CU. Discussion can be found upthread.

3 Polls Ending Feb 3 Extend the Delegate Compensation Trial Summary: This proposal would extend the delegate compensation trial up to a maximum of 6 months (through July 2022). Recommendation: Vote Yes. Pay is needed to both compensate delegates for time spent on governance activities and to entice new delegates into the ecosystem. Until MIP61 (or another delegate compensation MIP) can be approved, this extension is required to provide pay to Recognized Delegates. Offloading TUSD-A Summary: Rank the following options in order of preference -Activate liquidations on TUSD-A, which will liquidate undercollateralized vaults -No action -Create new TUSD-PSM that only accepts outflows of TUSD for DAI Recommendation: Vote (in order of preference) to activate liquidations, abstain, no action. Creating a new PSM simply to offload what little TUSD is still in the system (around $26 million worth) is not a good use of engineering time. Allowing any eligible vaults to be liquidated would clear it all out eventually (the stability fee is 1% and no new collateral can be added). Given that this legacy vault type is of manageable size, it is unnecessary to spend scarce resources on offboarding it. Turning on liquidations is easy, though GFX would expect to see the MIP62 Collateral Offboarding Process followed to offer users of Maker’s software to adjust their positions. Introduce Rate Limiting to Flap Auctions Summary: This proposal would authorize Protocol Engineering to alter the Flapper Contract to add parameters that can limit the number of DAI-for-MKR auctions that can occur simultaneously. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Several weeks ago, around 400 auctions were run in parallel, resulting in substantial numbers of below-market bids, including several auctions where the winner bid effectively 0 MKR for 30,000 DAI. This was a known exploit, but had not been prioritized to fix. While the auction format needs to be upgraded, this is a low-effort way to fix the exploit.

1 Poll Ending Feb 17 Increase the PSM-GUSD Debt Ceiling Summary: This proposal would increase the maximum capacity of the Gemini dollar (GUSD) Peg Stability Module from 10,000,000 DAI to 60,000,000 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is a @GFXlabs proposal. As articulated in the signal request, this is to increase diversification amongst redeemable, regulated stablecoins while not increasing exposure beyond that which can be covered by the Stability Buffer. 8 Polls Ending Feb 28 Facilitator Onboarding (DUX-001): 0xDeniz Summary: This proposal would onboard 0xDeniz as a facilitator to the DUX Core Unit. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is a planned succession within the Core Unit. @bainpm is stepping down to a less managerial role, and @0xdeniz is the candidate being put forward to lead the Core Unit. Modify Core Unit Budget (RISK-001) Summary: This proposal would modify the Risk Core Unit budget from a monthly spend rate of 182,000 DAI/month to 230,000 DAI/month. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The budget increase is largely driven by an expanding headcount and expansion of services provided to include more data analytics. An example of this is bringing @Makerburn within the Risk CU to ensure funding for the makerburn website. Modify Core Unit Budget (CES-001) Summary: This proposal would generally continue the previous budget of Collateral Engineering Services Core Unit, while also adding approximately 250k DAI to the Core Unit’s auditor wallet to maintain a 3-month runway. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This budget is generally in-line with the previous one, with only minor increases in overall payment from MakerDAO. MIP4c2-SP16: MIP 55 Amendments Summary: This proposal would amend MIP 55. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The changes are mostly housekeeping, with correction of typos in MIP55c1 and MIP 55c2, and increasing clarity in MIP55c3 around reduced oversight burden needed for Special Purpose Fund proposals at or below 50,000 DAI in expense. Modify Core Unit Budget (IS-001) Summary: This proposal would modify the Immunifi Security Core Unit by an increase of 69,000 DAI quarterly with an initial lump sum sent to the Core Unit’s auditor’s wallet of 138,000. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This increase in budget is to include operational audit MIP63c4-SP1: Onboard/Amend Keeper Network - TechOps Summary: This proposal would formally put the TechOps Core Unit’s operations of keeper infrastructure within the new MIP63 (Keeper Network) framework. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is largely an internal formality, and does not require additional budget or work that is not already being performed. Onboarding Maker Talent (MT-001) Core Unit Summary: This proposal would onboard the Maker Talent Core Unit with an annualized budget of 746,831 DAI and MKR vesting of 12.97/FTE. Recommendation: Vote Yes. There is a need to staff several CUs that are struggling. If this CU does not demonstrate an ability to source successful candidates for positions after several quarters, it can be offboarded. MIP60: Intangible Asset Assignment Summary: This proposal provides a process for managing intangible assets such as social media platforms on behalf of the DAO. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Currently there is no formal structure, which has historically served to block some CUs from access to certain assets, or has simply created confusion around who controls some assets.

MadShills:  This position seems at odds with the idea that offboarding is to be avoided and is a last resort / costly endeavor.   Thank you for the question. This particular CU (Maker Talent) is one that has fairly easy-to-measure metrics: Source candidates to fill vacant positions. While we don’t have an explicit number that is the line between underperforming and not, this CU is likely akin to Growth in that there are visible deliverables that easy to evaluate. Please don’t hesitate if you have other questions on GFX Labs’ positions!

1 Poll Ending Feb 24 MakerMan Retroactive Delegate Compensation Summary: This proposal would retroactively apply the current Recognized Delegate compensation formula to prior months. This would result in @MakerMan receiving 8245 DAI. No other delegates would be affected. Recommendation: Vote Yes. MakerMan initially missed payment in November due to falling just under an “all or nothing” threshold of participation. Recognizing this as a problem, governance has shifted to a compensation model that now proportionately lowers payment rather than a cliff to 0. Notably, MakerMan’s lowered activity level in November was a function of family health events, which highlights why the compensation model was shifted to be more flexible. 1 Poll Ending March 7 Greenlight Poll: PUNK (NTFX CryptoPunk) Summary: Signal support or opposition for onboarding this token as collateral. Recommendation: Vote Abstain. As mentioned in other votes, greenlight polls do not appear in practice to affect the speed or order that collateral is onboarded. Additionally, at this stage, there is often de minimus information available, and no due diligence or risk assessments have been performed.

2 Polls Ending March 3 Open Market Committee Proposal Summary: This proposal would alter the following parameters: Increase wstETH maximum debt ceiling (line) from 200m to 300m DAI Increase wstETH target available debt (gap) from 20m to 30m DAI Increase AAVE D3M line from 220m to 300m DAI Increase AAVE D3M gap from 50m to 65m DAI Decrease AAVE D3M target borrow rate (bar) from 3.5% to 2.85% Recommendation: Vote Yes. The increase in capacity for staked ETH provides more room for one of the few avenues of growth for the protocol. Similar reasoning can be applied for the Aave direct deposit module. As the use of D3Ms increases, however, Maker needs to come to terms with a more sustainable policy for managing them, as the protocol is a price taker, not a price maker, and artificially suppressing interest rates on the market could have negative effects upon the DAI <> USD peg. Adding Rate Limiter to Flap Auctions Summary: This proposal would add a new parameter (lid) to the surplus (flap) auctions. It would initially be set at 150,000 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The surplus auctions need upgrading to a new format, but in the meantime, this is a low-effort fix for the problems seen when $60m in ETH was liquidated, resulting in several million DAI of surplus auctions triggered in parallel. This parameter will prevent that from occurring in the future, and the initial level would limit parallel auctions to no more than 5 at a time. @GFXlabs supported the current executive spell, which included our own proposal to raise the debt ceiling on GUSD-PSM, and a small retroactive compensation to @MakerMan
GFX Labs supported the current executive. It contains payments to various CUs and delegates, as well as some parameter changes. Views and opinions on all of them can be found higher in this thread.

2 Polls Ending March 10 Offboarding Parameters for TUSD-A Summary: This proposal would set the on-chain parameters for the orderly offboarding of the remaining TUSD collateral in the Maker protocol. These include, among other things, setting the liquidation penalty to 0 and incentivizing keepers to kick the auctions. Recommendation: Vote Yes. All but two small vaults are already eligible for liquidation, should they be re-enabled. TUSD-A is a vestigial vault that has not allowed new users for quite some time, so this is the on-chain portion of the offboarding process, which should be coupled with off-chain components to make users aware who may wish to avoid liquidation. Reinstate Surplus Buffer Lerp Summary: This proposal would lower the ceiling to the Surplus Buffer from 250 million DAI to 60 million DAI. This ceiling would increase in a linear fashion to 90 million DAI over the next 30 weeks. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This would return to the currently adopted MKR burning policy after emergency responses were made to the “Flappy Friday” event that resulted in very inefficient surplus auctions. Any permanent changes to this policy should be run through governance processes. GFX Labs supported the out-of-sequence executive spell, which addressed a possible exploit in how flash loans and the Emergency Shutdown Module interact.

GFX Labs supported the most recent executive. It included the final implementation of Curve stETH-ETH LP collateral, bug bounty payouts, and a patch to limit the number of flap auctions occurring simultaneously.

2 Polls Closing March 17 Fund Ambassadors Pilot Program Summary: This proposal would fund the MakerDAO ambassador program with 25,000 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This program historically (under the Foundation) focused on translations and materials for non-English speakers. This is urgently needed, and the initial focus to shore up neglected ties to Latin America are the perfect first step. The spend is small, and the need is clear. It is likely this will provide outsize value for the miniscule budget. Amend MIP64 to Clarify Critical Web Bounty Amount Summary: This proposal would alter payouts for bugs classed as Critical from ≤ 50,000 DAI to = 50,000 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is a minor alteration, proposed by the Immunefi Core Unit.

9 Polls Closing March 28 Declaration of Intent – Invest in Short-Term Bonds Summary: This MIP13 declaration of intent would signal that MakerDAO has an official policy of pursuing investment in short-term bonds with a portion of its stablecoin reserves. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Details will be important for any implementation, but as would be assumed from GFX’s prior proposals to onboard short-term Treasury bills and notes, this is important for risk management, and should provide revenue as well. Facilitators Offboarding: SHOP-001 Summary: This proposal would offboard both of the facilitators of the MakerDAO Shop Core Unit. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Both facilitators have indicated a willingness to step down and that they are unlikely to be able to give the Shop CU the attention to execute. Onboard Gelato to the Keeper Network Summary: This proposal would add Gelato to the MIP63 Keeper Network. That includes 1,000 DAI/day budget, with min and max buffers of 4,000 and 20,000 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Gas costs are low currently, but keeping activities often require gas in times of network congestion. Keeper network allows Maker to subsidize these costs to ensure a robust keeper network exists. In this case, it is for 1,000 DAI/day, and with a small buffer that will not exceed 20,000 DAI. The costs are small, and a healthy keeper network is vital to the security of the Maker protocol. Onboard Keep3r to the Keeper Network Summary: This proposal would add Keep3r to the MIP63 Keeper Network. No current subsidy is requested at this time. Recommendation: Vote Yes. See the previous poll to onboard Gelato. Keep3r does not currently require a subsidy while they operate pro bono, but are anticipated to need one in the future. Rapid Payment for Small Bug Bounties Summary: This proposal would add 115,000 DAI/month to the Immunefi Core Unit’s budget, so that small bug bounties could be paid without delay through the CU’s operational wallet rather than waiting on executive spells. Recommendation: Vote No. There isn’t a demonstrated need for an additional 1,380,000 DAI annually to process small bug bounty payouts quickly. This proposal does not specify what “small” is in terms of payment, and the CU’s operational wallet currently holds excess DAI, with another quarter million DAI available in the auditor’s wallet. Also, a request for two small payments took only 9 days from request on the forum to payment. In short, there just doesn’t seem a reason to 1) increase the effective budget for the core unit at this time, 2) bypass the existing process. If a bug bounty hunter has earned a small payout and would experience hardship in waiting for a week or more, then the Immunefi CU should make that payment and request reimbursement from governance. MIP61: Recognized Delegate Compensation Summary: This proposal would establish a formula for monthly compensation to Recognized Delegates. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This proposal has been a long time in coming to a vote, and while most proposals can benefit from iteration, this is a clear improvement over no compensation for delegates or a continuation of emergency compensation measures. Modify Core Unit Budget (GOV-001) Summary: This proposal would fund the GovAlpha Core Unit for another 12 months. The monthly stream would increase by 250 DAI/month to 89,983 DAI/month. There is also a one-time allocation of 30,000 to increase the continuity fund (for contingencies) to 180,000 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. It’s a rare budget at MakerDAO that doesn’t request large increases. That this budget continues the old one with de minimis changes sets an example for other core units. The only notable increase is to add to the core unit’s contingency fund. Modify Core Unit MKR Budget (GOV-001) Summary: This proposal would provide a MKR vesting plan for GovAlpha contributors. This would be approximately 67 MKR/year per full-time equivalent. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The requested MKR is among the lowest, and GovAlpha provides mission-critical services to the DAO. It also has the distinction of being the only CU with a track record of returning excess funding, having done so twice. This reputation for conservative budgets deserves, if anything, slightly more MKR or DAI than has been requested in this governance cycle. Modify Core Unit Budget (RWF-001) Summary: This proposal would increase the existing Real-World Finance Core Unit budget from a monthly spend of 155,000 DAI to 685,000 DAI, as well as formalize some improvements to the flow of funds to the CU from the DAO. It would include a one-time transfer of 2,055,000 DAI to the contingency fund due to the increased overall rate of budgeted expense. Recommendation: Vote No. This is an ambitious budget proposal, which would increase the monthly spend by more than 300%. The bulk of the expenditure is earmarked for anticipated legal costs associated with onboarding new real-world asset originators. RWF CU would become, under this proposal, the largest core unit by cash expenditure, eclipsing even Protocol Engineering. The nature of the request – funds specifically to perform legal due diligence on counterparties – is a good one. But this is a serious amount of money being requested, and so a serious weighing of risks and benefits is required. The main risk appears to be simply that there is not a demonstrated history of demand to support half a million DAI in expenses on legal each month. In theory, unused funds would be returned to the DAO. This is, however, a song that many core units sing, and unused funds get rolled over because ever-increasing budgets require ever-larger contingency funds. This very budget proposal is an example of that. Despite a slight surplus at the moment, no funds will be returned, because a larger budget requires a larger reserve. Until a history of core units returning excess capital to the DAO materializes, we feel it is best to reverse this tradition of assuming unspent funds will be returned. Even if funds are indeed returned, those funds could have been deployed elsewhere. After a sleepy autumn and winter, MakerDAO is beginning to ponder aggressive growth strategies that require every penny of reserves to backstop that growth and keep the protocol sound. Given rumblings of doing a capital raise through debt or token issuance, any excess DAI that is overbudgeted could incur costs to replenish in the Surplus Buffer. Finally, for a request of this size – effectively going from second gear to top speed – it seems prudent to ensure there is an ability for the underlying deals to close and the assets to deliver cash flow. Even if every DAI is spent exactly as imagined, there is still little clarity on how long it will take to recoup a profit on this investment. We encourage the Real-World Finance CU to return with a more modest budget request. It is simply unclear at this time whether this money can be spent as envisioned, and if that spend would create value for the protocol. After several deals have been closed, a budget request of this size would be more appropriate. Until then, scope a budget that is for the next quarter, and we can all revisit whether the pipeline is maturing as hoped.
As is typical, GFX Labs supported the current executive. This executive spell contained a small bug fix to ESM and supported implementation of the current governing token contract for TUSD.

4 Polls Ending March 31 Onboard Notional Finance D3M Summary: This proposal would direct core units to investigate and assess implementation of a DAI Direct Deposit Module for the 3-month maturity pool on Notional Finance. Note that the margin of Yes vs No will affect the prioritization score for this proposal vs other approved collateral proposals. Recommendation: Vote Yes, but GFX will Abstain. This is GFX Labs’ proposal, so we fully support it. This provides a low-risk “bolt on” opportunity for meaningful revenues, while also strategically expanding Maker’s monetary policy control into the front end of the fixed-rate curve for DAI. Due to a disclosed conflict of interest, we have pledged not to vote at the on-chain poll stage. MIP62 Amendments Summary: This proposal would amend MIP62 (Collateral Offboarding) to remove references to the Content Core Unit, which is no longer active. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is housekeeping to maintain an up-to-date MIP62. ETHAmsterdam Event Special Purpose Fund Summary: This proposal would allocate 50,000 DAI for a MakerDAO event in Amsterdam during an industry conference scheduled between April 20-24, 2022. Recommendation: Vote No. There has been no stated business purpose for the event this is requested for. It is modeled on an event that occurred at ETH Denver and paid for by various core units, but that event appears not to have provided any clear benefit despite enormous spend. That there is no plan to even track who attends, harvest their information, or mine it for potential business partners or job talent is striking. Additionally, 30,000 DAI has apparently already been taken from the budgets of four core units for a deposit on the venue for this event, implying that if this 50,000 DAI is not approved, the DAO will lose the money deposited. This 30,000 DAI was sourced from multiple core units, including two technical core units whose mandates do not seem consistent with the funding of social events with no clear business purpose. There is simply no reason to rush a spend of at least 80,000 DAI on an event with no clear purpose or payoff. Maker already suffers from a reputation of core units spending too much money – let’s not add weight to that notion. If this event has clear value it can deliver, then there will be no shortage of future industry conferences to host one. At the moment, this appears to be an unnecessary expense at a time Maker is actively discussing raising capital. Initial Parameters for StarkNet Simple DAI Bridge Summary: This proposal would establish an initial limit of 5,000,000 DAI for the StarkNet simple bridge. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This initial limit is in line with MakerDAO’s standard practices with regards to risk exposure with new assets and technical implementaions.
As should be expected, GFX supported the current executive. These were largely DAI and MKR expenses for approved Core Unit budgets, as well as some support to the keeper network.

2 Polls Ending April 7 Open Market Committee Proposal Summary: This proposal would alter the following parameters: Decrease wstETH Stability Fee from 2.5% to 2.25% Decrease CRV ETH/stETH Stability Fee from 3.5% to 2.25% Decrease WBTC-A Stability Fee from 3.75% to 3.25% Decrease WBTC-B Stability Fee from 5% to 4.5% Decrease G-UNI DAI/USDC (.05%) Stability Fee from 0.1% to 0% Decrease G-UNI DAI/USDC (.01%) Stability Fee from 0.25% to 0.05% Increase available debt (gap) for G-UNI DAI/USDC (.05%) from 10m to 50m DAI Increase AAVE D3M target borrow rate (bar) from 2.85% to 3.5% Increase maximum debt ceiling (line) for G-UNI DAI/USDC (.05%) from 100m to 750m DAI Increase maximum debt ceiling (line) for G-UNI DAI/USDC (.01%) from 750m to 1b DAI Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is a difficult basket of proposals to approve. For the most part, they are correctly reacting to market conditions and Maker’s need to halt losses in market share. The committee is making sensible recommendations. On the other hand, this is projected to lower revenues by approximately 6 million DAI. Note that MakerDAO is already operating at a more than 10 million DAI loss in the absence of large liquidation fees. Given governance’s tendency to approve nearly all spending proposals while rejecting revenue-generating proposals, the loss of revenue will be felt. A wider discussion about fiscal discipline is necessary in the face of market headwinds. GFX hopes that delegates who share this concern (such as @MakerMan, @JustinCase, and @Doo_StableLab, among others) and the @strat-fin-core-unit are open to collaborating to build a series of specific proposals to reduce expenditures where they would be felt the least, freeing up funds to allocate towards efforts that will be accretive to protocol income. Launch Maker Wormhole With Optimism & Arbitrum Domains Summary: This proposal would deploy the Maker Wormhole, with initial support for the Optimism and Arbitrum chains. Initially, each domain would have a maximum of 1m DAI exposure and 0 fees for users to make fast withdrawals. Recommendation: Vote Yes. MakerDAO and the Maker protocol have both lagged DeFi peers such as Aave and Uniswap in launching a multichain strategy. Initiating the “test level” of support for an official, safe, trusted method of DAI transfer is a massive positive. As more domains are added and confidence grows enough to increase exposure to the Wormhole, this

1 Poll Ending April 14 Adjust CRV V1 ETH-stETH-A Parameters Summary: This proposal would change the following parameters for the Curve LP ETH-stETH ilk: Increase maximum debt (line) from 5,000,000 to 50,000,000 DAI Increase target available debt (gap) from 3,000,000 to 10,000,000 DAI Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is a new ilk that went live a month ago. It has held the initial low-millions in collateral with no technical issues. It is appropriate to increase the debt ceiling to a meaningful amount, while keeping it below the current surplus buffer. GFX Labs also supported – as usual – the current executive, which included delegate pay, SPF funding for an event at ETH Amsterdam, and increasing the DC of the same ilk voted upon in the poll referenced above.
GFX Labs supported the urgent out-of-sequence executive. Delegates and several large holders did an excellent job securing the protocol.

2 Polls Ending April 18 Amend MIP64 (MIP4c3-SP3) Summary: This proposal would amend MIP64 so that the scope of impacts covered under the bug bounty program administered by the Immunefi Security Core Unit can be modified at the discretion of IS CU. Recommendation: Vote No. If scope needs to be expanded or contracted under MIP64, let it be explicitly stated there, and not refer to an external source (the Immunefi website). Note that no announcements of changes are required under this amendment, and presumably have no boundaries on what could qualify (or not) for a bounty or how quickly those boundaries could shift. That being said, we understand it can be difficult to write proposals in a comprehensive manner with so many potential details, and we will attempt to comment more frequently prior to voting. Whitelist Oasis.app on Multiple Oracles Summary: This proposal would allow Oasis.app to read current and queued price data on the following MakerDAO oracles: ETH wstETH WBTC renBTC YFI UNI LINK MANA Recommendation: Vote Yes. Oasis is an important UI and partner for the DAO. GFX Labs would support giving the Oracles CU discretion to add/remove whitelisted actors without requiring a vote. As usual, GFX supported the current executive, which offboarded legacy TUSD vaults, as well as providing funding for several approved programs and core units.

12 Polls Ending April 25 Governance Communications Mandate Refresh (COM-001) Summary: This proposal would reword, clarify, and slightly expand the mandate of GovComms CU. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Changes are reasonable and mainly serve to clarify the existing role of the core unit. Dissolution of Content Production, MKT-001, Multi-Sig Summary: This proposal would remove the multi-sig for Content Production CU (MKT-001) from the list of recognized multi-sigs of the DAO. The multi-sig currently has no funds but does have a small unclaimed funding stream of 3,800 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. There is, of course, a chance this proposal will be front run to claim the remaining funds before this multi-sig can be wound down. But the funds are not large and this is a housekeeping measure. GFX Labs would support the explicit delegating of this process in the future, when front-running may carry a cost and to reduce burden on governance. Attn: @GovAlpha-Core-Unit Adding CES-001 as a Collateral Onboarding Domain Team Summary: This proposal would onboard the entire Collateral Engineering Services CU as a domain team under MIP7. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This largely formalizes CES CU’s position within vestigial MakerDAO “law” under MIP7 and MIP8, and also potentially interacting under MIP9. GFX Labs would support further cleanup of these three MIPs, should @GovAlpha-Core-Unit and/or @collateral-core-unit wish to take up the task. Modify Collateral Application Form Summary: This proposal would update the collateral application form (used primarily for MIP6 applications). Recommendation: Vote Yes. Most of these updates originate in past experiences and a desire to standardize information format and disclosure. The first step to a fair process is a standardized process. Pairwyse Licensure (MIP66) Summary: This proposal would license the Pairwyse protocol IP for MakerDAO in exchange for 4,000 MKR and 15% of vault fee revenue transacted through Pairwyse. Recommendation: Vote No. This is simply too expensive for what it offers. The underlying technology looks innovative and may find market fit. However, Maker is already straining under cost of developing an in-house fixed rates solution with nearly identical costs. It seems an imprudent use of funds to pay for licensure of Pairwyse when the utilization of D3Ms for fixed-rate protocols like Element and Notional can be done for a fraction of the price, development of the already-approved Term Lending Module, or utilization of the already-approved Maple D3M and proposed TrueFi D3M could provide MakerDAO with the same exposure without the legal liability or expense. Methodology and Review Process for Structured Finance Transactions (MIP67) Summary: This proposal would formalize a process for the onboarding of structured finance transactions. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is an improvement over the current process. It does not, however, define what constitutes a structured finance transaction. To avoid overlapping mandates of too many core units in the first step of this process, we would like to see clarification as to what specifically constitutes a structured finance transaction. That being said, it is a clear improvement over the status quo, and has our support. Thank you, @Real-World-Finance @luca_pro @christiancdpetersen and others who authored this proposal. Modify Core Unit Budget: Protocol Engineering (PE-001) Summary: This proposal requests a 12-month budget of 7,590,000 DAI (632,500 DAI per month). Recommendation: Vote Yes. This represents a 24% increase over the prior year’s budget, which is significant. Note that the previous year’s budget was well executed and resulted in a 130,599 DAI surplus. Most of this increase is accounted for by increased salaries (PE proposes to fill new jobs within the core unit) – 895,750 DAI. This represents increased investment in the engineering and development capacity of the protocol, and we support this. Other changes include increased travel budget and decreased contingency buffer and increased emergency funding to reflect the higher run rate of expenses. An effort was made to justify the increased head count in this post, and we find it a reasonable justification that this increased expense will result in greater capacity to develop, deploy, and maintain new products for the protocol. Modify Core Unit Budget: Data Insights (DIN-001) Summary: This proposal requests a 12-month budget of 1,083,000 DAI (90,250 DAI per month) and a MKR vesting plan of 330.48 MKR over 36 months (33.895 MKR per FTE annually). Recommendation: Vote No. This represents greater than 50% increase in the DIN CU operating budget, mainly driven by new hires to expand the scope of services provided by DIN to expand to L2s and RWA. We feel DIN provides a useful service, but mainly provides support to specific CUs. There is not a clear need for it to be its own CU – and feel similarly about other service CUs that appear to be vendors rather than core functions that need to be under governance supervision to secure the protocol. GFX would support a budget neutral restructuring to allow DIN to provide the same services it does now and for equivalent income, but without requiring the oversight of governance. That is to say, transitioning to a higher budget for those CUs that utilize DIN (and other vendor CU) services while unwinding DIN as a formal CU would be supported by GFX. If the CUs that act as the end users of DIN products request an increase to pay for expanded DIN services, we would also generally support that. This type of restructuring would 1) lower governance overhead, 2) grant CUs the autonomy to choose and manage relationships with vendors as they see fit. Modify Core Unit Budget: GovComms (COM-001) (Core Budget) Summary: This proposal requests a 6-month budget of 2,093,258 DAI. Recommendation: Vote No. On an annualized basis, this represents a 30% increase from the current 6-month budget. This expense is driven by 37,000 DAI in employer taxes that was not in the previous budget, as well as 72,000 DAI increase in operating expenses. There is also around 50,000 DAI increase in salaries and hourly compensation spread across 4 FTEs. GovComms has generally performed a satisfactory job at its current level of spend. It is unclear what additional operational efficiencies or cost savings for the DAO will be the reward for this increased spend. GFX recognizes that annual raises can be appropriate, particularly if contributors are advancing in seniority to reflect higher levels of skill. The overall 15% increase in compensation seems large. If this is due to seniority advancement as a result of increased skill and productivity, please note that, given the large increase. Of most concern are the large increases in employer taxes and operating expenses. How were these so small (8,000 DAI) in the current budget but a combined 110,000 in the new one? Were the funds from another category backfilling this expense? Or has the expense increased dramatically? The proposal does show that around 20,000 DAI of these expenses were previously covered in another line item, but that still leaves a lot of increased spend. We would like to see whether the current budget is actually insufficient or if the new budget reflects large spending increases in the employer taxes and operating expenses categories before voting yes on a new budget for this CU. This CU has ample emergency funds to cover any gap in funding between now and a future budget. Modify Core Unit Budget: GovComms (COM-001) (Budget Expansion) Summary: This proposal requests a 6-month budget of 2,643,678 DAI and would supercede the previous GovComms poll if approved. Recommendation: Vote No. This budget is the same as the previous one, but with an additional hire as a Public Relations Project Manager. There is no one filling this role in the DAO currently, but GovComms, with its focus on internal and stakeholder communications, should focus on its core competencies that it is already doing well, rather than attempt to fill this gap. For other reasons, see ones inherited from above. Add Events Core Unit (EVENTS-001) Summary: This proposal would onboard the Events Core Unit, which would focus on planning, organizing, and executing MakerDAO-branded events. It requests a 12-month budget of 898,150 DAI and onboards 1 facilitator. Recommendation: Vote No. There has not been a clear argument made for how this spending either lowers costs, increases revenue, or improves products produced by the Maker protocol. The focus to date has been on large events at Ethereum conferences, with no commitment to even collect the contact information and names of those who attend. That provides poor optics at a time that there are active discussions of raising capital, MKR holders are denied the burner mechanism, and an assortment of other opportunities to deploy this capital are obvious. At the end of the day, this spend could be better deployed to PE, CES, Growth, or one of the (prospective or current) CUs associated with the RWA program, all of which have more obvious rewards for increased spend by improving the capacity of the protocol or the DAO to deliver, deploy, maintain, or integrate new products. We also refer to the opinions in the Data Insights budget request that this prospective CU appears to be a vendor. In the event that these services are argued to be worth the expense, we would prefer to see CUs who value those services fit the provision of those services into their budgets. Even when taken at face value, there is little reason for governance to have direct oversight of an Events CU, when that could fall under some combination of Growth, a future marketing CU, or even conceivably technical CUs (for hackathons) or GovComms/GovAlpha (for stakeholder exclusive events). Update Data Insights CU Mandate Summary: This proposal would modify the DIN CU mandate to include a focus on Layer 2, cross-chain, and RWA datasets. Exact text may be found in the link. Recommendation: Vote No. As stated with regards to DIN-001 budget request, we would support a budget-neutral unwinding of this CU to allow it to service CUs as customers without direct oversight or interference from governance. This would remove governance micromanagement of vendor selection (by pre-funding a CU for a given service), and DIN is part of an independent entity that is developing products for other counterparties and does not need either the boundaries of a mandate or the direct oversight of MakerDAO governance. As usual, GFX Labs supported the current executive, which is mostly concerned with various Oracles housekeeping tasks.

2 Polls Ending May 2 Greenlight Poll: sETH2 (Stakewise Staked ETH) Summary: This poll asks whether the asset should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker Protocol. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The relevant core units should investigate this asset. Staked ETH is rapidly becoming a preferred collateral in DeFi, and more diversity of staked ETH as accepted collateral is prudent to explore. Greenlight Poll: Huntingdon Valley Bank Loan Syndication Summary: This poll asks whether the asset should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker Protocol. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The terms suggested as a starting point are more sophisticated – a yield spread over a benchmark, for instance – and the counterparty a highly regulated US depository institution. Maker is in dire need of reliable counterparties with a willingness to scale and a track record of experience. HVBC’s willingness to retain 50% of the loans they originate provides more alignment of any partner who has approached MakerDAO to date. Over time, HVBC intends to request lowering this retained portion, which may be appropriate if performance is as expected. If the relevant CUs can arrive at a legal structure that is both acceptable to HVBC and protects the DAO’s most-senior debt position, then the economics of this partnership hold great promise for everyone involved. It is easy to imagine a strategic partnership where the DAO can contract with HVBC to originate loans fitting specific criteria. Even without any partnership beyond this proposal, the commercial mortgages and loans in this application are potentially material to the DAO’s earnings and financial health.

As usual, GFX Labs supported the most recent executive, which was largely related to core unit distributions. 2 Polls Closing May 5 Investigate Implementation of TrueFi D3M Summary: This proposal would direct core units to investigate implementation of a TrueFi D3M. Recommendation: Vote Yes. A portfolio approach to D3Ms (DAI Direct Deposit Modules) allows for risk diversification across counterparties and their underwriting practices. A positive result here would begin work on the technical implementation and clear the way for TrueFi to submit a particular pool management team for onboarding in the future. TrueFi likely brings access to markets where existing collateral options and D3Ms are not present, and can provide an accretive way to increase the use of DAI. Open Market Committee Rate Proposal Summary: This proposal would alter stability fees in the following manner: Decrease WBTC-A Stability Fee from 3.25% to 2.25% Decrease WBTC-B Stability Fee from 4.5% to 4.0% Recommendation: Vote Yes. Market share for Maker in the wrapped bitcoin markets overall, and this rate adjustment will end the risk premium of WBTC filtering through to the rate. At the end of the day, despite its name, Maker is a price taker on rates, and must follow market rates generally. The loss of revenue is not to be celebrated, but users of the protocol will find fewer attractive alternatives with this cut of WBTC rates back to the same levels as ETH. 2 Polls Closing May 16 Greenlight Poll: ATDC (ATD Combustors) Summary: This poll asks whether ATDC should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker protocol. The proposal can be viewed here. Recommendation: Vote No. This is an extensive proposal meant to appeal to Maker’s “Clean Money” initiative. Unfortunately, it is not necessary to evaluate the merits of this proposal due to the clear risk-reward mismatch. This proposal would create a credit line from the protocol for 5 years with a coupon of 2-2.5%. This is strictly worse than the risk-free rate, which at writing is 3.01% for US Treasury 5-year notes. Maker should not signal to the market that it is interested in any off-chain collateral that is lower yielding than the risk-free rate unless that collateral has similar credit risk as US Treasury debt obligations. Positive environmental effects are “nice to have” but can never substitute for taking below-market rates for comparable risk. We thank Oasis Pro Markets for all the hard work in sourcing and preparing this proposal. It was professional and generally thorough, and we hope they will continue to seek out large potential partners. GFX Labs is supporting the current executive. It contains delegate pay, some rate cuts to WBTC ilks, and onboards the stETH-B ilk

2 Polls Ending May 19 Raise Emergency Shutdown Module (ESM) Threshold Summary: This proposal would raise the ESM threshold from 100,000 MKR to 150,000 MKR. Recommendation: Vote Yes. GFX Labs proposed successfully a number of months ago to raise the ESM threshold from 75,000 MKR to 100,000 MKR. We also support raising it again. Ideally, ESM can be removed someday in the future. As the value guarded by the protocol grows, it is important to increase the resources required to shut it down. This would require more than 15% of all MKR to shut down the protocol permissionlessly. Adjust the lid Parameter on the Rate Limited Flapper Summary: This proposal would adjust the lid parameter from 150,000 DAI to 30,000 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This parameter change would allow for only a single flap (DAI surplus) auction at a time, rather than five. That level of throughput may allow politically for the burner to be re-enabled, which may appease some vocal small MKR holder voices recently who have raised concerns that paid contributors have easy access to the protocol’s revenues, while MKR holders themselves receive no benefit. Whether or not the flap auctions are the ideal mechanism for this, a controlled, constant burn would be a way to ensure that MKR holders – who ultimately bear the most risk backstopping the protocol as recent events with LUNA/UST have shown – receive some compensation, even if it is small and indirect.

5 Polls Ending May 23 Modify Core Unit Budget – Strategic Happiness (SH-001) Summary: This proposal is for 180,000 DAI/quarter + 50,000 DAI (one-time restocking) budget for the Strategic Happiness Core Unit. It would also include a 250 MKR vesting over 4 years with an 18-month cliff. Recommendation: Vote No. The initial budget for Strategic Happiness was small enough to be experimental. It is, unfortunately, not a good time for MakerDAO to commit more than three-quarters of a million DAI to swag distribution. Additionally, the MKR vesting is approximately what a member of the Oracles CU – a mission-critical core unit – would receive. A sharply reduced budget that was similar in scale to the previous budget would be supported, even if it included a small increase to offer some part-time compensation to the facilitator who has been working pro bono until now. Amendment to MIP40: Budget Process Summary: This proposal would amend the current budget process in a number of ways, including creating a regular budget cycle cadence, mandating return of unspent funds before any new ones are disbursed, and increased granularity in reporting actual expenditures. Recommendation: Vote Yes. While this will be an increased reporting burden on core units, these are largely quality-of-life improvements (synchronizing a “budget season”) and needed oversight considering the sums of money being spent. In order to mitigate the increased burden, budgets that have 10% increase or less are exempted from some of the requirements. Budgets that would be >10% increase will also be required to have a continuity budget to accompany the requested increase so that the choice for MKR holders is not “increase funding or cut to 0.” MIP69: L2-to-L1 Fast Withdrawals Summary: This proposal would deploy the first iteration of Maker Wormhole, which would allow DAI fast withdrawals from Arbitrum and Optimism to Ethereum. Recommendation: Vote Yes. While not without risks, the expansion of the Maker protocol to L2s and other chains is vital to allow more crypto-native growth. With such large market share on Ethereum, there are few routes to growth on-chain without this expansion. Later planned upgrades will include StarkNet, as well as L2-to-L2 teleportation of DAI. MIP68: Monetalis Lusitano, UK Green Economy SME Wholesale Lending Summary: This proposal would authorize the financing of a bond backed by a SME lending portfolio. Fees would be 2.00% annually + 80% profit sharing (as detailed within the proposal). The expected duration would be 10 years, but the bond would be puttable. The requested initial debt ceiling is 50,000,000 DAI, with an imbedded mechanism to increase to 100,000,000 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Abstain. At 105% collateralization, this collateral relies heavily upon appropriate marking. The precision required to properly mark the backing of this bond may prove difficult, particularly in a timely manner. A robust set of agreements in place to purchase liquidated or underperforming portions of the portfolio would be needed. While we have had no shortage of improvements we would like to see – and to some extent are beginning to see – from the RWF Core Unit, it makes us very uncomfortable to bypass the MIP6 process to onboard this proposal in a self-contained manner. In particular, this has prompted Monetalis to provide its own testimonials and assessments by individuals in the lending industry who feel they are credit worthy. Unfortunately, there appears to be potential for conflicts of interest. For instance, Mr. Abrahams formerly served as Head of Operations at Singer & Friedlander, which is now part of Shawbrook Bank. Mr. Ashworth formerly worked at Lombard. Shawbrook and Lombard are two lenders that would stand to sell most of the initial portfolio to Monetalis. These individuals may be very practiced in this field, but probably shouldn’t serve as a substitute for RWF CU’s evaluations. With regards to RWF concerns, we do note that Monetalis has recently announced it plans to onboard a partner to supply a junior tranche of financing. As for the proposed legal structures, the 6S Capital structure highlights how unforeseen expenses can have deleterious impact upon revenues remitted to the protocol. In that case, the fees accrued amount to less than the expenses of the real-world trust, meaning that less than the initial principal is apparently owed for repayment. Even if the legal vehicle performs exactly as anticipated, it is clear that an understanding of associated fees is needed up front. There has not been a clear statement that some form of currency hedging program will be implemented (since DAI are fixed to the dollar and Monetalis will be providing financing denominated in GBP). It would be prudent to have one in place, and one that can be sustained with the low yields projected for Monetalis. Overall, the proposal appears to have improved significantly from the original MIP6. However, the yield is quite low, realistically it requires a term commitment from Maker to avoid selling the portfolio prior to maturity, and the risk-reward just does not look favorable. It looks unlikely to be a disaster, but the money for the effort to implement and monitor simply isn’t compelling. As a result, this is a difficult proposal to support. For now, we simply find it too difficult to evaluate the potential reward, and do not feel confident all of the risks are yet understood, and will be abstaining. MIP65: Monetalis Clydesdale, Liquid Bond Strategy & Execution Summary: This proposal would establish Monetalis as executor of up to 500,000,000 DAI in bond strategies. The intention is to swap to USDC to lower exposure to Circle. Recommendation: Vote Yes. In many regards this proposal addresses the same issues as GFX’s own proposal to utilize US Treasury bills to lower direct exposure to USDC. This MIP reads as though there will still be further approval required for any strategies prior to deploying any DAI/USDC. Assuming the legal structure is considered sufficient by the various RWA core units/proposed core units, this should have fairly minimal execution risk on the part of Monetalis, and the 15 bps fee seems fair compensation for simply moving from DAI to dollars in a custodial account (or multiple, as Monetalis has stated a desire for multiple managers). The true risk comes from what bond strategies are ultimately approved. It is not clear that MakerDAO has the in-house expertise to wisely choose strategies. In particular, there should be special focus on both liquidity and preservation of capital, which will likely result in fairly low-yielding strategies. We strongly encourage the DAO to avoid looking at this MIP as a means of getting yield. Yield should materialize, but it is mainly a risk management move, to mitigate potential risk from such a concentrated counterparty. The mechanical implementation should not be difficult for Monetalis to execute, assuming it is given reasonable guidance by the DAO on bond strategy. Executive As usual, GFX Labs supported the current executive. It contained MKR vesting, fixed a minor bug in flash loans, and continued L2 technical work.

3 Polls Ending May 26 Investigate Implementation of an Antalpha Institutional Vault Summary: This proposal would direct the relevant core units to investigate how to implement an institutional vault for Antalpha, and provide risk assessments on that potential implementation. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Antalpha is an OTC and lending company. The origination fee of 1% and discount of 50 bps for ETH and WBTC vaults should encourage long-term use of DAI. The size is manageable, with 500,000,000 DAI limit requested each for the two collateral types. Yes, core units should perform preliminary work and present risk assessments for final approval. Investigate Deploying the MakerDAO Balance Sheet in ETH Summary: This proposal would direct the relevant core units to investigate options for deploying a portion of the MakerDAO balance sheet into ETH. Recommendation: Vote No. Ether is a volatile asset. The Maker protocol is not especially well capitalized, so utilizing DAI from the stability buffer to purchase ETH provides a poor risk-reward without appropriate hedging strategies. Even more risky would be using the stablecoins in the PSMs to buy and hold/LP/stake ETH. Maker is already extremely exposed to the price of ETH through use of vaults. Should Maker choose to invest in crypto assets for income generation or asset appreciation reasons, it should solicit requests for proposal (RFP) from professionals with good track records. Launch Maker Teleport with 1 Basis Point Fee Summary: This proposal would launch Maker Teleport (previously known as Maker Wormhole) with a 1 bp fee. Recommendation: Vote No. It is difficult to imagine a scenario where 1 bp would generate material fee, but it does provide friction to users. With no material revenue to be generated, focusing on the best possible user experience seems prudent. If volumes rise to such a point 1 bp becomes significant or demand is inelastic enough for a larger fee, then that can be revisited. At the least, this bridge serves as the only pegging mechanism for DAI between chains so that an Optimism DAI = Arbitrum DAI = Ethereum DAI. Just as we keep the PSMs friction free, so should the bridge until some other mechanism is available on each L2 to assist in maintaining a fixed exchange rate. As usual, GFX Labs supported the current executive, which vests MKR and raises the threshold to the ESM.

1 Poll Ending May 30 Greenlight Poll: FEI Summary: This poll asks whether the asset should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker Protocol. Recommendation: Vote Abstain. Normally, it would not seem like overcollateralizing FEI to mint DAI would be a large market. It’s difficult to see a compelling use case beyond Tribe itself minting against its native token. If so, perhaps a specific deal should be negotiated with Growth to do an institutional vault for large amounts of Tribe’s ETH collateral. The proposal as it stands seems difficult to evaluate without addressing the usage by Tribe, and whether that would account for oracle costs. Abstain.

8 Polls Ending June 2 Offboarding Parameters: UNI-A Summary: This proposal would set the following parameters: Liquidation penalty to 0% Debt ceiling to 0 Flat kick incentive (tip) to 0 Dss-lerp to target 30 days to reach maximum liquidation ratio Set end parameter for dss-lerp liquidation ratio to 3x highest collateral ratio vault in this ilk Recommendation: Vote Yes. This ilk has low usage that makes it a cost center after accounting for oracles budget. Offboarding Parameters: UNI V2 DAI/ETH-A Summary: This proposal would set the following parameters: Liquidation penalty to 0% Debt ceiling to 0 Flat kick incentive (tip) to 0 Dss-lerp to target 30 days to reach maximum liquidation ratio Set end parameter for dss-lerp liquidation ratio to 3x highest collateral ratio vault in this ilk Recommendation: Vote Yes. This ilk has low usage that makes it a cost center after accounting for oracles budget. Offboarding Parameters: UNI V2 WBTC/ETH-A Summary: This proposal would set the following parameters: Liquidation penalty to 0% Debt ceiling to 0 Flat kick incentive (tip) to 0 Dss-lerp to target 30 days to reach maximum liquidation ratio Set end parameter for dss-lerp liquidation ratio to 3x highest collateral ratio vault in this ilk Recommendation: Vote Yes. This ilk has low usage that makes it a cost center after accounting for oracles budget. Offboarding Parameters: UNI V2 UNI/ETH-A Summary: This proposal would set the following parameters: Liquidation penalty to 0% Debt ceiling to 0 Flat kick incentive (tip) to 0 Dss-lerp to target 30 days to reach maximum liquidation ratio Set end parameter for dss-lerp liquidation ratio to 3x highest collateral ratio vault in this ilk Recommendation: Vote Yes. This ilk has low usage that makes it a cost center after accounting for oracles budget. Offboarding Parameters: UNI V2 WBTC/DAI-A Summary: This proposal would set the following parameters: Liquidation penalty to 0% Debt ceiling to 0 Flat kick incentive (tip) to 0 Dss-lerp to target 30 days to reach maximum liquidation ratio Set end parameter for dss-lerp liquidation ratio to 3x highest collateral ratio vault in this ilk Recommendation: Vote Yes. This ilk has low usage that makes it a cost center after accounting for oracles budget. Open Market Committee Proposal Summary: This proposal would make the following changes: Reduce wstETH-A max debt (line) from 300,000,000 to 200,000,000 DAI Reduce AAVE D3M line from 300,000,000 to 100,000,000 DAI Reduce LINK-A line from 100,000,000 to 50,000,000 DAI Increase MANA-A line from 10,000,000 to 15,000,000 DAI Reduce AAVE D3M target borrow rate from 3.5% to 2.75% Increase wstETH-B line from 15,000,000 to 30,000,000 DAI Recommendation: Vote Yes. Dislocations in the Aave markets due to the end of liquidity incentivization makes the line reduction appropriate, and the target rate reduction should have only slight downward pressure on the market while increasing revenues. Increasing exposure to MANA is appropriate, given the high fees charged on that ilk, as well as it being one of the few areas of the Maker portfolio at all time highs. Short Ratification Poll for MIP10c7-SP2 – Modify Oracle Data Models Summary: This proposal updates the mix of sources utilized by the data model, with changes based on which venues have the most liquidity and volume. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Oracles CU has submitted this request in order to keep the oracles model using the most relevant price feeds. Short Ratification Poll for MIP10c19-SP1 – Update Oracle Expiration Time For All Oracles Summary: This proposal would raise the medianizer expiration time from ~4.3 hours to 24 hours. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Oracles CU has submitted this request after determining that timing expiration (rather than spread) is the main driver of oracle back end updates. This is expected to have significant gas savings. This does not affect updates based on spread.
GFX supported the executive to disable the Aave D3M. This was at the request of Maker Risk.

3 Polls Ending June 16 Deploy A Trial Permissionless Open Market Operation Summary: This proposal would deploy and utilize the new DssKiln. 3,000,000 DAI would be streamed to the contract over three months, which would sell lots of 30,000 DAI for MKR. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is similar to the flap auctions, so is a good test case for DssKiln. Current market conditions are favorable for buying back MKR as well. Management of Velodrome Airdrop and veNFT Summary: This proposal authorizes a management framework for an expected airdrop of veVELO from the Velodrome protocol on Optimism. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This veVELO is an airdrop, and as a windfall asset that is also locked in Velodrome governance for the next 4 years, Maker may as well use it to its benefit. Add rETH Vault Type Summary: This proposal offers the following (among other) initial parameters and would authorize onboarding a vault type for rETH: Stability Fee: 2.25% Liquidation Ratio: 170% Dust: 15,000 DAI Maximum Debt Ceiling: 5,000,000 DAI Target Available Debt: 3,000,000 DAI Recommendation: Vote Yes. Rocket ETH is a competitor to Lido Staked ETH. While less liquid, it does appear to be growing in market depth and the initial parameters limit exposure to a manageable size while experimenting with this ilk.

11 Polls Ending June 27 Ratification Poll for Onboard Growth Task Force (MIP75c3-SP1) Summary: This proposal would onboard a Growth Task Force under MIP75 (unratified currently, but included in this cohort of polls). This Task Force would be provided 1,000,000 DAI and pursue objectives including (but not limited to) a capital raise, recruitment initiatives like hackathons, and positioning Maker as a credit wholesaler. Funds would be controlled on a discretionary basis by the 7 of 9 multisig included in the proposal. NB: This is a Ranked Choice poll with the following choices: Abstain Approve Task Force with delegated authority to spend funds Approve Task Force without delegated authority to spend funds Reject Task Force Recommendation: Vote Reject Task Force (primary and only choice). Leaving aside that MIP75 appears to have been proposed specifically to allow the Growth Task Force to exist, the scoped mandate for this task force is broad and meandering. Bundling hackathons to recruit technical talent with broadly unpopular ideas like a capital raise and undefined ways to support a multi-chain growth strategy is simply too much for one proposal. 1,000,000 DAI left to the discretion of 9 individuals without a defined, narrow goal presents significant risk of misallocation to the wrong implementation, or simply spreading the funds across too many priorities. Multiple members of the multisig also regularly express views on strategic direction that GFX simply does not agree with and does not want to see enacted because of poor risk-reward tradeoffs. The primary example is a desire to pursue a capital raise, which we are currently strongly opposed to in all forms until preceded by demonstrated need and improved spending discipline. For more general views on the proposed MIP75, please see the comments for that poll. Facilitator Onboarding to IS-001: @psychonaut Summary: This proposal would promote J. Pritkin (aka Psychonaut) to being a facilitator of the Immunefi Core Unit. He is currently a deputy facilitator. Recommendation: Vote Abstain. This appeared to be a fairly straightforward title bump + mandated actor privileges. However, a notable and respected member of the MakerDAO community recently posted a strong anti-recommendation. It is difficult to feel like we have an informed opinion at this stage. Facilitator Onboarding to DIN-001: @tadeo Summary: This proposal would promote Tadeo to being a facilitator of the Data Insights Core Unit. He is currently a full time contributor. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The outgoing facilitator has recommended Tadeo, who has also been the contact point for delegates and community members for a while. He is familiar with the core unit and has always been both willing and able to deliver needed data in our experience. Adding Lending Oversight Core Unit (LOVE-001) Summary: This proposal would onboard the Lending Oversight CU, with an annualized DAI budget of 984,000, a one-time seed transfer of 410,000 DAI, and an annualized MKR budget of ~63.5 MKR/full-time contributor on average. While not binding in this proposal set, SES CU has pledged to reduce its incubation program budget to offset the monthly budget of LOVE, if approved. Recommendation: Vote No. The mandate for this core unit seems unfocused in terms of deliverables. Perhaps the specific deliverables are difficult to articulate on a medium such as the forum, but it is not clear what milestones the CU would be measured against. Initiatives on its proposed roadmap include generalized frameworks, educational support to DAO members, and overall providing a “second set of eyes” on structured finance deals that include MakerDAO. We recognize that an independent review of real-world asset deals is important, there are already Real World Finance, Collateral Engineering Services, and the incubated Legal & Transaction Services CUs involved in these projects. The most obvious role for LOVE would be to provide risk assessments, similar to Risk CU’s relationship to Protocol Engineering CU when onboarding a crypto-native asset. The mandate as written – particularly the third initiative – suggests LOVE would perform more of an assessment of the assessments, presumably through a financial lens. The DAI price is material, but not extraordinary. But the MKR compensation is quite high, commanding levels of MKR that are akin to what a member of Oracles CU (which is mission critical) would receive. For senior staff, this would be even higher at ~111 MKR, which is considerably more than any other non-technical core unit. For reference, this amount would be between the MKR received by DECO and CES. Notably, the two full-time contributors already onboarded would receive this amount, so the 111 MKR/person/year seems the appropriate number to judge (rather than an average of 63.5 when fully staffed with two junior contributors). Perhaps it’s appropriate, but it appears the 2 junior staff would get 16 MKR/year while the 2 already-hired senior staff would get 111 MKR/year. (Note that this does not include the repricing option, which the two staff would likely exercise given depressed market conditions) Overall, this is just an extraordinary amount of MKR for non-technical talent. MIP75: Task Forces Summary: This proposal would allow a framework or MakerDAO to formally recognize groups “responsible for coordinating high-level business decisions on behalf of the DAO. They may also work with an associated discretionary fund to realize business objectives.” Recommendation: Vote No. This seems like a step backwards, by returning to specially empowered individuals and discretionary funds. The very nature of the proposal is to roll back oversight and remove “stop, look, listen” portions of public debate and input. This seems more like the early stages of a DAO that has not yet decentralized, and not appropriate for a DAO that has already made the transition away from special groups sharing private details with only “top delegates” while actively excluding smaller delegates, MKR holders, and the Maker community overall. Adding Special Purpose Fund – Makershire Hathaway (MIP55c3-SP4) Summary: This proposal would authorize Strategic Finance CU (in collaboration with Risk CU and prospective LOVE CU) to pursue yield generation strategies and support DAI liquidity/utility. Funding would be 10,000,000 DAI Recommendation: Vote No. This mandate is too broad, and not under the direct supervision of governance. Given the relatively simple strategies being proposed – such as providing DEX liquidity for MKR and DAI pairs – there isn’t an obvious reason to delegate 10,000,000 DAI to multisig. We are generally supportive of the more conservative, passive strategies and encourage Strategic Finance to bring proposals for lump-sum or D3M funding that are controlled directly by governance. MIP16 Amendments Summary: This proposal would alter the governance cycle to allow more time for technical work when implementing parameter changes. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Protocol Engineering has often expressed the view that the original spell-writing cadence was suboptimal. MIP74: Permissionless Open Market Operations Summary: This proposal would allow the DssKiln module to perform authorized open market operations. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The DssKiln seems to function similar to flap auctions. Making it modular to work with other tokens is a useful tool. Budget Ratification: Strategic Finance (SF-001) Summary: This proposal would allocate either a continuation of the existing SF CU budget (~990,000 DAI) or an expanded budget of ~1,300,000 DAI annualized. NB: This is a Ranked Choice poll with the following choices: Abstain Approve Increased Budget Approve Existing Budget Only Reject Budget Recommendation: Vote Existing Budget Only (first choice), Reject Budget (second choice). The expanded budget represents an increase of >30%. We don’t feel there was a compelling argument made that the size of the increase would result in lower costs or higher revenues for MakerDAO. Onboard Keep3r Network (MIP63c4-SP4) Summary: This proposal would provide a monthly stipend with minimum 4,000 DAI and maximum 20,000 DAI to Keep3r Network, as described by MIP63. Recommendation: Vote Yes. A healthy keeper network is important for the safety of the protocol. This stipend defrays the gas and other minor operational expenses of a keeper. Budget Ratification: Growth (GRO-001) Summary: This proposal would allocate annually either a continuation of the existing Growth CU budget (~3,270,000 DAI) or a “bear market” expanded budget (~4,200,00 DAI) or “base growth” expanded budget (~5,000,000).
