NB: This is a Ranked Choice poll with the following choices: Abstain Approve “Base Growth” Expansion Approve “Bear Market” Expansion Approve Existing Budget Only “Brandless Growth” Reject Budget Recommendation: Vote Existing Budget Only (first choice), Reject Budget (second choice). Both budget expansions are significant, which is partly reflective of incubating a Brand CU. The Brand CU has expressed the view that Maker’s product is vaults and leverage, rather than DAI. We simply disagree with this, as DAI is what sets the Maker protocol apart from Aave or Compound protocols. A branding effort focused on the currency rather than lending would be something we would be willing to reconsider in the future. Because we do not support the intended messaging of the incubating Brand CU, we do not support either of the expanded budgets.
Thank you for supporting rETH with your vote, the rocket pool community is hot with anticipation - to use the vault and we pray for your support on the follow on executive poll when it comes!

As usual, GFX supported the two previous executives. One consisted of MKR disbursement in preparations for vesting in DECO and RWF CUs. The other consisted mainly of MKR disbursement to RISK CU for vesting and finalized the offboarding of several unprofitable ilks.

3 Polls Ending July 7 Add RWA-009 (HVBank) As New Vault Type Summary: This proposal would onboard HVBank as a real-world asset originator. The initial debt ceiling will be 100,000,000 DAI. Fees will be handled outside the vault level, and further details can be found in the proposal. Rates will be benchmarked off of SOFR. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is a major first step in partnering with a US depository institution, and should provide income that is uncorrelated with the movements of crypto assets. Maker Open Market Committee Proposal Summary: This proposal would alter rates and parameters on several vault types. The notable changes are below, with a complete list in the proposal. Increase GUNI V3 DAI-USDC (.05%) Stability Fee from 0% to 0.01% Increase UNI V2 DAI-USDC Stability Fee from 0% to 0.01% Increase wstETH-A Stability Fee from 2.25% to 2.50% Reduce USDC-A Stability Fee from 1% to 0% Reduce USDP-A Stability Fee from 1% to 0% Recommendation: Vote Yes. Raising some fees a modest amount is appropriate. Lowering the fees on vestigial stablecoin vault types will stop the current accrual of bad debt (which results in phantom DAI in the Surplus Buffer). Several debt ceiling lowerings were also included, mainly on LINK, YFI, MATIC, and wstETH. Select A Target Level Of rNPI Profitability To Guide Budget Cuts Summary: This proposal asks MKR holders for guidance on whether MakerDAO should aim to accumulate DAI in the Surplus Buffer, break even, or allow negative cash flow with a minimum of 3 years of runway). Recommendation: Vote Abstain. We have some marginal disagreements with how current financials are reported, and so do not feel it is appropriate to suggest a specific level profitability based upon them, particularly without knowing what budget cuts would be required to meet a specific goal. As usual, GFX Labs has supported the current executive, which includes delegate pay, Keep3r Network stream, and several million in core unit streams and direct transfers.

1 Poll Ending July 14 Add RWA-008 (OFH) as a new vault type Summary: This proposal would (when executed on chain) close a deal with Societe-General Forge to refinance a tokenized covered bond pool. Debt ceiling would be at 30,000,000 DAI, with a Stability Fee of 5 bps. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This transaction has been nearly a year in the making since becoming public. The relationship built with SocGen, proof of concept to the financial world, and diligence demonstrated in dotting every i and crossing every t have already proven useful. The amount is small by Maker’s standards, and though the fees are only 5 bps and will not offset the legal expenses, it is a deal worth doing. 1 Poll Ending July 25 Governance Facilitator Onboarding GOV-001 Summary: This proposal would onboard Patrick_J as a facilitator of the GovAlpha Core Unit. The core unit currently has only one facilitator after LongForWisdom stepped back into a contributor-only role. Recommendation: Vote Yes. @Patrick_J has already been fulfilling many of the duties and will be able to rely upon Prose11, who is a more senior facilitator in the core unit, should he have questions or need further mentoring. As usual, GFX supported the current executive, which contained minor parameter changes.
As usual, GFX Labs supported the current executive. The closing of the HVBC and SocGen deals are history in the making!

Greenlight Poll - bIBTA (Backed Finance Short-Term Bond ETF) Summary: This poll asks whether bIBTA should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker protocol. Recommendation: Vote Abstain. This token would be a redeemable share of IBTA. Because this token is not yet launched, it is unclear what secondary liquidity would be available, what the effects of redemption only during business hours would be, how important the financial strength of the issuer is when it comes to redemption, and what the costs of oracle feeds would be. Because of these questions, we prefer to wait until after the token is launched before considering it for collateral, but do recognize the possible potential.

3 Polls closing August 4 Open Market Committee Proposal Summary: This proposal would alter the following parameters: Reduce the ETH-B Stability Fee from 4% to 3.75%. Reduce the WSTETH-A Stability Fee from 2.50% to 2.25%. Reduce the WSTETH-B Stability Fee from 0.75% to 0%. Reduce the WBTC-B Stability Fee from 4.00% to 3.75%. Increase the GUNIV3DAIUSDC1-A Stability Fee from 0.01% to 0.02%. Increase the GUNIV3DAIUSDC2-A Stability Fee from 0.05% to 0.06%. Increase the UNIV2DAIUSDC-A Stability Fee from 0.01% to 0.02%. Increase the GUNIV3DAIUSDC2-A Maximum Debt Ceiling (line) from 1 billion DAI to 1.25 billion DAI. Increase the GUNIV3DAIUSDC1-A Maximum Debt Ceiling (line) from 750 million DAI to 1 billion DAI. Increase the MANA-A Maximum Debt Ceiling (line) from 15 million DAI to 17 million DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Unfortunately, the Maker protocol has struggled to convince users to generate DAI through vaults. It is not a good sign that in a rising-rate environment, Maker must cut rates yet again to retain users, but the outflows from stETH in particular and flat usage of ETH-B suggest a cut may be appropriate. Gradually raising rates on LP collaterals is also appropriate, as users need to become accustomed to actually paying for vault usage. Maker Teleport Deployment to StarkNet Summary: This proposal would add StarkNet to Maker Teleport. Initial parameter would be with a 1,000,000 DAI maximum exposure, which would bring the total maximum exposure from Maker Teleport to 3,000,000 (StarkNet, Optimism, and Arbitrum each with 1,000,000). Recommendation: Vote Yes. Maker Teleport is a key strategic asset for Maker’s multi-chain future. It will allow DAI to be officially minted by Maker on each chain and enjoy rapid transport between chains. The work for StarkNet’s addition is completed, and now it is a matter of deploying it and observing it in the wild. Tactical Re-allocation Process for Budget Adjustments Summary: This proposal would direct the following to occur: “The Strategic Finance Core Unit will co-ordinate the budget re-allocation process with Core Unit, MKR holders and Recognized Delegates” Recommendation: Vote Abstain. It’s not clear how this would be different from what occurs already. Disagreements seem to be in the details or philosophical in nature. That said, it seems fairly harmless as a poll, and we are not actively opposing it. As usual, GFX is supporting the current executive, which follows through on previous commitments.

1 Poll Ending Aug 15 Greenlight Poll: Pando Summary: This poll asks whether Pando Investment Grade Climate Assets should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker Protocol by the Core Units. Details of the collateral can be found here. They are generally a pool of rated solar loans originated by Mosaic Solar, Inc. The yield for Maker would be 2%, with an expected term of 14 years. This would be amortizing (shrinking in balance). Recommendation: Vote Abstain. To be frank, the yield is not suitable when it is significantly below similar maturity yields on US Treasuries, which do not bear credit risk. The duration of this collateral also seems inappropriate for MakerDAO’s limited ability to design and execute a portfolio-wide strategy. Additionally, there does not appear to be junior capital at stake (only yield) for Pando. With that in mind, however, Pando is presenting the collateral as a value proposition partly on Maker’s Clean Money sentiment. The symbolic value of approving this collateral pool is difficult to judge, making it difficult to understand if it offsets the weaknesses of the financial structuring of the deal. 6 Polls Ending Aug 22 Modify Dai Foundation CU Budget Summary: This proposal requests a budget of either 723,357 DAI, 667,055 DAI, or 325,688 DAI to continue funding Dai Fonden over the next 12 months. Dai Fonden a Danish foundation which holds much of the intellectual property related to the Maker protocol. This is a ranked choice poll. Recommendation: Vote 667,055 DAI budget. The Dai Foundation safeguards important trademarks such as the Dai and Maker trademarks. This includes taking action against misuse of Maker-related intellectual property and defending the legitimate use of that intellectual property. Because MakerDAO is a loose collection of individuals and entities that develop and market the Maker protocol software, it is not a legal entity and cannot own these intellectual properties in its own right. Funding Dai Fonden is a necessary expense, but does not require the highest requested amount, given that there is no major litigation on the horizon and budgets are currently constrained. Amendments to Core Unit Offboarding Process (MIP4c2-SP15) Summary: This proposal amends the core unit offboarding process with enhancements to streamline and make more orderly the offboarding and unwinding process. The goal is to make the process less disruptive to the overall DAO, and the specific details can be found here. Recommendation: Vote Yes. An early version of this was initiated by GFX, and further refined to the current form by @twblack88. These changes represent a much-needed upgrade to the offboarding process. Modify Oracles Core Unit Budget Summary: This proposal requests either 5,061,125 DAI or 4,554,575 DAI over the next 12 months. The lower budget request is accompanied by a commitment from Maker governance to exclude Oracles CU from any future budget cuts for the duration of this budget period. This budget does not include ETH for oracle contract gas. This is a ranked choice poll. Recommendation: Vote 4,554,575 DAI budget. Oracles represent critical infrastructure for the Maker protocol, and cannot be quickly replaced should it not be fully maintained. While we are uncomfortable with committing to shield Oracles CU from any further budget reductions irrespective of the fiscal state of the protocol, the good faith compromise offered here is a good deal, and we believe governance should take it. MIP76: Makershire Redux Summary: This proposal creates a 10,000,000 DAI pool for yield generation in DeFi protocols. The mandate would only support stable LPs. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This revised proposal removes the dependence in previous versions upon multi-sigs and has a scope limited to stablecoin strategies related to DAI, USDC, and USDP. With revenues appearing to have bottomed, utilizing some of the Surplus Buffer for an experiment seems appropriate. Offboarding Events Core Unit Summary: This set of proposals would offboard the Events Core Unit, removing all budget and providing a one-time payment of 103,336 DAI as a “golden parachute.” Recommendation: Vote No. This is a difficult decision. We are fully in agreement that Maker does not need this core unit, and support it being offboarded or subsumed under another core unit that could properly direct its efforts. The creeping process by which this core unit was onboarded also makes us uncomfortable. That being said, this core unit is the newest in MakerDAO. It is slated for offboarding before having a track record to evaluate. Maker governance needs to break from its reputation of mercurial changes in policy, and it is too early to remove this core unit. With immediate improvements in the offboarding process being voted upon right now and coming harmonization of budget cycles, we recommend against a disorderly offboarding at this time. Without a strong pivot to uses other than pure social events or demonstrable evidence of value by the time this core unit has been active for 6 months, we will still support future offboarding once the amendments to core unit offboarding have been approved. The current recommendation is based upon procedural grounds and concern for reputational risk. Initiatives like the Governance Voting Initiative announced two days ago are directionally what would make us comfortable maintaining the budget for this core unit. After review, GFX is as usual supporting the current executive, which includes execution of previously approved actions and steps to reverse the DAI flow from Genesis.
Have always liked the way GFX summarizes polls, executives etc.   Setting the standard for delegates to follow as always! Great job @GFXlabs

1 Poll Ending Aug 18 Maker Teleport Deployment on Starknet Parameters Summary: This proposal would initiate a 1 basis point fee for fast withdrawals, and raise the deposit limit from 50 to 1000 DAI for the StarkNet Maker Teleport deployment. Recommendation: Vote Yes. We are not entirely supportive of a fee attached to Maker Teleport, but certainly support raising the deposit limit from 50 to 1000 DAI as the next baby step for this portion of Maker Teleport.

2 Polls Ending Aug 25 Target Spend Level Summary: This proposal aims to establish a target spending level for MakerDAO over the next 6 months, with several options. No Change (the option to reject instituting a policy from this poll) 15 million DAI 15.5 million DAI 16 million DAI 16.5 million DAI 17 million DAI 17.5 million DAI NB: This is a ranked choice poll. Recommendation: Vote No Change. MakerDAO could sorely use a cap on total spending. Unfortunately, it’s difficult to do that without first assessing needs and priorities, as well as accounting for the current financial position. This poll should be revisited once other questions large (like strategic direction) and small (like exactly which wallets are DAI belonging to core units vs the DAO) are answered first. Collateral Onboarding Project Based Funding Request Summary: This proposal asks for MKR tokenholder approval for the Collateral Engineering Services (CES) CU to spend up to 44,000 of the professional services line item and 55,000 of the contingency buffer line item for assorted expenses related to onboarding and maintenance of real-world assets. Recommendation: Abstain. In our opinion, CES does not need permission to utilize already-allocated resources for activities within its mandate. 3 Polls Ending Aug 29 Greenlight Poll: BlockTower Credit Summary: This poll asks whether BlockTower Credit should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker Protocol. Recommendation: Vote Yes. BlockTower is offering junior capital, attractive yield, and is itself a top 15 MKR holder. The risk-reward deserves evaluation and initiating the due diligence process. Greenlight Poll: Cabot Renewable Energy Crypto Mining LLC Summary: This poll asks whether Cabot Renewable Energy Crypto Mining LLC should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker Protocol. Recommendation: Vote No. The main collateral for this proposal are around 3,000 MicroBT M30+ mining machines. A casual search of prices shows even at the high end these machines appear to cost $4,000/each. Even allowing for no depreciation of the machines, that provides a 100% LTV. When adding in the additional complexity of a novel jurisdiction in Paraguay, this proposal would require too much work for an already strained RWA pipeline. Greenlight Poll: Detox Digital Coin (DDC) Summary: This poll asks whether DDC (Detox Digital Coin) should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker Protocol. Recommendation: Vote No. This project seeks financing to develop US commercial real estate for substance abuse recovery facilities. Given the refinance/market risk for exiting the portfolio once it is fully developed and the niche market where Maker has no existing expertise, this project is not a good fit for Maker at this time, and would add to the pressure of the current RWA pipeline. We wish the applicant the best in addressing this very real need.

2 Polls Closing September 1 Open Market Committee Proposal Summary: This proposal provides two buckets of parameters to change, with two affirmative options: Option 1: Increase the WSTETH-B Maximum Debt Ceiling from 100 million DAI to 200 million DAI. Increase the CRVV1ETHSTETH-A Maximum Debt Ceiling from 5 million DAI to 50 million DAI. Increase the CRVV1ETHSTETH-A Target Available Debt from 3 million DAI to 10 million DAI. Decrease the CRVV1ETHSTETH-A Stability Fee from 2.25% to 2.0%. Decrease the MANA-A Stability Fee from 6% to 4.5%. Option 2: All of Option 1, as well as Decrease the ETH-A Stability Fee from 2.25% to 1.5%. Decrease the ETH-B Stability Fee from 3.75% to 3.0%. Decrease the WSTETH-A Stability Fee from 2.25% to 1.5%. Decrease the WBTC-A Stability Fee from 2.25% to 2%. Decrease the WBTC-B Stability Fee from 3.75% to 3.5%. Decrease the RENBTC-A Stability Fee from 2.5% to 2.25%. NB: This is a ranked choice poll. Recommendation: Abstain. Because MakerDAO rates have the potential to influence the overall DeFi rates markets and GFX Labs’ involvement with Interest Protocol, GFX Labs is generally abstaining from granular rates adjustments for the foreseeable future. SPF: Legal Domain Work on Greenlit Collateral (bIBTA) Summary: This Special Purpose Fund would provide 50,000 DAI to Strategic Finance Core Unit to reimburse for legal expenses related to due diligence and onboarding bIBTA. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Strategic Finance has agreed to front this expense after the unexpected deterioration of the Real World Finance Core Unit has left it inoperable. This is a modest expense, and the bulk of legal expenses are usually being shouldered by applicants, which accounts for the small size of the allocation. As usual, GFX Labs supported the previous and current executive spells, which mainly contained executables related to HVBC and Maker Teleport

4 Polls Ending September 8, 2022 MIP55c3-SP8: Legal Work on MIP65 Special Purpose Fund Summary: This special purpose fund would reimburse Strategic Finance (SF-001) Core Unit for advancing funds for legal work on MIP65. This special purpose fund is for a one-time allotment of 30,000 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is reimbursement to SF-001 for work that would normally have paid for by RWF-001 prior to that latter core unit’s decision to halt ongoing work. MIP4c3-SP4: MIP65 Amendments Summary: This amendment would remove the requirement of the RWF-001 facilitator to verify legal and governance process appropriateness under MIP65. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This change was endorsed by the current RWF-001 facilitator, whose core unit appears to be winding down. MKR Pro-Rata Vesting for Former RWF-001 Members Summary: This proposal would distribute 121.42 MKR divided between two former RWF-001 contributors who left/were terminated by the RWF-001 facilitator prior to their MKR vesting cliff. Recommendation: Vote No. The cliff of vesting exists for a reason. If these contributors found employment within a current or new Core Unit, their vesting would resume. But neither made it the one-year cliff. This poll is already being used to ask for further exceptions by the Strategic Happiness Core Unit facilitator. The RWF-001 disintegration is regrettable, but a contributor’s relationship is with their facilitator, not with the DAO, which informally contracts with the facilitator. Updating HVBank Legal Agreements (RWA-009) Summary: This proposal makes some changes to the underlying documentation for the Huntingdon Valley Bank legal agreements. The details may be found at the proposal link, but can be described as a slight expansion of authorized loan types for the HVBC portfolio. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This does represent an expanded number of explicitly authorized loan types, such as bridge loans. This seems within the original intended scope of the deal, however. Other changes are similarly looser, but only marginally so – such as minimum credit score being replaced with an average credit score. This is acceptable and has been recommended by MakerDAO’s legal advisors. 3 Polls Ending September 19, 2022 Greenlight Poll - GUNI-V3-BUSD/DAI Summary: This poll asks whether this asset should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker Protocol by Core Units. Recommendation: Vote No. This asset has a TVL of $535.30 as of writing. Maker does not need to bootstrap BUSD-DAI liquidity, no material revenues typically emerge from G-UNI vaults, and there is no clear market for this. If Arrakis Finance wishes to subsidize Maker’s oracle costs or demonstrate a large market demand, then this would be worth reconsidering. Greenlight Poll - UNI-V3-wBTC/renBTC Summary: This poll asks whether this asset should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker Protocol by Core Units. NB: This is poll, despite the title, is indicated to be for Gamma Strategies’ ERC-20 token (similar to Arrakis’ tokens) for the underlying pool mentioned. Recommendation: Vote No. This asset has not yet launched, and similar ones (a bespoke pool with more limited governance just for Maker onboarding) are low TVL. See the same reasoning as the one for G-UNI BUSD/DAI above. If Gamma wishes to subsidize Maker’s oracle costs or demonstrate a large market demand, then this would be worth reconsidering. Greenlight Poll - GNO Summary: This poll asks whether this asset should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker Protocol by Core Units. Recommendation: Vote No. Given Maker’s costly oracles, it’s unclear how this asset could generate enough debt to pay for itself. Liquidity begins to deteriorate before $2m of swaps on decentralized exchanges, suggesting this asset could not be both safely and profitably onboarded without either cheaper oracles or an alternative liquidation backstop. As usual, GFX Labs supported the current executive spell, which included a number of previously approved distributions and parameter changes.
As usual, GFX Labs supported the current executive, which included a variety of disbursements and housekeeping. Full details of the executive contents can be found in the link.

1 Poll Ending October 3, 2022 Greenlight Poll: RFA (Canadian Federally Regulated Mortgage Originator) Summary: This poll asks whether the asset RFA (RFA - Canadian Federally Regulated Mortgage Originator) should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker Protocol by the Core Units. Recommendation: Vote Yes. These are uncertain times where governance is undergoing structural changes, but like the now-closed HVBC deal, this appears to be worth expending effort on. Access to highly regulated, stable markets like Canadian mortgage lending offers diversification and yield that the Maker protocol needs. 6 Polls Ending September 26, 2022 Amend Measurement Period for Delegate Participation Metrics Summary: This proposal would alter the measurement period for Recognized Delegate participation and communication from a cumulative lifetime total to a rolling 120-day window under MIP61c2. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This would encourage delegates to remain active after periods of personal absence by allowing for rehabilitation without waiting months to become eligible for payment again. GFX Labs authored this proposal. MakerDAO Delegates MIP Set Summary: These three MIPs (77, 78, and 79) would superceded MIP61 to govern the Recognized Delegate Program. MIP 77 revises the responsibilities of Recognized Delegates, as well as how their participation is tracked. MIP 78 revises delegate DAI compensation by raising the maximum monthly payout, and altering the slope of the curve which determines DAI per MKR delegated. MIP 79 provides the first MKR compensation plan to delegates. This also includes retroactive MKR vesting to delegates that were compensated under MIP61 and the initial Delegate Compensation Trial. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Raising the cap on MKR compensation allows for continuing the trend towards professionalized governance by dedicated teams with specialized expertise. It also finally aligns Recognized Delegate incentives more fully with the protocol by establishing MKR vesting. StarkNet Engineering Core Unit MKR Compensation Summary: This proposal would provide an average of 135 MKR per full-time equivalent annually for 3 years, with a 1-year vesting cliff to the StarkNet Engineering CU. Recommendation: Vote No. This amount is too much, and approximately twice what Oracles Core Unit members receive. The StarkNet CU is deserving of MKR compensation, but it should be in proportion to the ability of the recipients to cause harm or deliver revenue to the protocol. Special Purpose Fund for Ambassador Program Summary: This proposal would disburse 81,000 DAI for the provision of non-English language educational materials about the Maker protocol and MakerDAO. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Maker found some of its earliest adoption outside of the Anglophone world. All DeFi projects need more exposure to, and educational materials for, the non-English speaking population of the world. Particularly for stablecoins, some of the most compelling use cases are outside of the US and Commonwealth countries. GovAlpha Core Unit MKR Compensation Summary: This proposal would provide MKR vesting compensation to the GovAlpha Core Unit. The options are: Option 1 (CU preferred): 200% multiplier applied: 330.27 total MKR (153.61/FTE/year) Option 2: 150% multiplier applied: 247.70 total MKR (115.21/FTE/year) Option 3: 100% multiplier applied: 165.14 total MKR (76.81/FTE/year) Option 4: Reject MKR vesting. NB: This is a ranked choice poll Recommendation: Vote Option 3, Option 2, Option 1. GovAlpha is an important part of MakerDAO, but their ability to deliver revenue to or inflict harm upon the protocol is generally low. MKR vesting should be in proportion to those two capabilities. Strategic Happiness Core Unit Offboarding Summary: This proposal would offboard the Strategic Happiness Core Unit, reducing its budget to 0 and removing its facilitator as a mandated actor. A severance of 45,000 DAI would be provided. Recommendation: Vote Yes. MakerDAO is subject to sharp budget constraints, and a core unit focused on swag is not needed. With irregular reporting and oversight, it makes sense to offboard this core unit.

GFXlabs:  GovAlpha is an important part of MakerDAO, but their ability to … inflict harm upon the protocol is generally low   Don’t wish to cause commotion or draw undue attention to this vote, but this part of the reasoning should be acknowledged as patently false. The Governance Facilitator holds many points of trusted judgement that are specified by active MIPs. Electing a Governance Facilitator should be done with with great care because of it. Not only are plenty of malicious actions much easier to launch from a trusted Core Unit like GovAlpha, but general incompetence also puts a high tax on the Maker community. I appreciate your vote of confidence that GovAlpha deserves MKR compensation, but must wave a big caution sign at the insinuation that the Core Unit, that maintains all voting portal and MIP related additions, could cause limited harm. @Patrick_J and myself would never abuse this trust, which is why I vouched whole heartily for Patrick’s appointment. But our good intentions should not cover up the great responsibility that comes with being the dedicated Governance Core Unit.

2 Polls Closing September 29, 2022 Update rETH Onboarding Parameters Summary: This proposal would set onboarding parameters to the following (making previously approved parameters obsolete where they disagree): Decrease Stability Fee by 0.75%, from 2.25% to 1.5%. Decrease Auction Price Multiplier (buf) by 0.1, from 1.2 to 1.1. Increase Max Auction Drawdown (cusp) by 0.05, from 0.4 to 0.45. Decrease Max Auction Duration (tail) by 20 minutes, from 140 minutes (8,400 seconds) to 120 minutes (7,200 seconds). Decrease Flat Kick Incentive (tip) by 50 DAI, from 300 DAI to 250 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Rates are overall lower and liquidity for rETH higher than when this collateral was initially approved, leading to these updated recommendations by the Risk Core Unit. Collateral Auction Parameter Updates Summary: This proposal would lower the buf parameter by .1 on the following collaterals. The buf parameter is the multiplier for beginning prices on Maker liquidation auctions, so this represents lowering the beginning auction price by 10% of the oracle price. ETH-A ETH-B ETH-C WBTC-A WBTC-B WBTC-C WSTETH-A WSTETH-B CRVV1ETHSTETH-A LINK-A MANA-A MATIC-A RENBTC-A Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is likely to result in shorter settlement time for auctions, from an estimated 9 to 13 minutes, depending upon collateral. It does expose the user to less relief in the event of a rapid recovery in price while collaterals are being auctioned, but quicker auctions protect the protocol against unexpected losses, which is the primary mission of the protocol.

2 Polls Ending October 6, 2022 Open Market Committee Parameter Proposal Summary: This proposal would alter the following parameters: Decrease the CRVV1ETHSTETH-A Stability Fee from 2% to 1.5%. Decrease the YFI-A Maximum Debt Ceiling (line) from 25 million DAI to 10 million DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. These ilks have potential, but are poorly utilized. The lower rates on the Curve LP are intended to increase usage, and the lower debt ceiling on YFI-A is to lower the maximum exposure on a collateral that is not currently being used at all. Offboarding of YFI may be appropriate if usage cannot get above 0. Approve Multisig for Management of Velodrome NFT Summary: This proposal would approve a ¾ multisig on Optimism to manage voting with an airdrop earmarked for MakerDAO by Velodrome. The 4 signers are all delegates or former delegates: MakerMan, juanbug (Penn Blockchain), ultraschuppi, and rspa (Flipside Crypto). Recommendation: Vote Yes. Ongoing litigation by the Commodities and Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) vs Ooki DAO, attempts to establish liability through voting participation. Unlike holding ENS or stkAAVE in the Pause Proxy, this airdropped asset is intended to be used to vote through the Velodrome governance portal, which made this vote more difficult than the formality it was expected to be. That being said, this is not a space where zero risk is practical, and we hope the revenues are worthwhile. Maker is in a much stronger position than most when it comes to political and capital resources to defend itself, and while it should weigh the risk and reward of different actions, should not hide out of fear. As usual, GFX Labs supported the two most recent executive proposals, which formalized already approved actions on chain.

5 Polls Ending October 13, 2022 Whitelist Oasis.app on rETH Oracle Summary: This proposal would whitelist Oasis to consume data from the rETH oracle. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This process should be reformed to allow open access. Change Parameters for GUSD-PSM Summary: This proposal would alter the following parameters for the GUSD Peg Stability Module: Increase the PSM-GUSD-A Fee Out (tout) from 0bps to 20bps Increase the PSM-GUSD-A Maximum Debt Ceiling (line) from 60 million DAI to 500 million DAI Increase the PSM-GUSD-A Target Available Debt (gap) from 10 million DAI to 50 million DAI Recommendation: Vote No. Increasing the line and gap seems entirely appropriate in light of the unilateral offer of Gemini to provide revenue sharing when the PSM is north of 100m GUSD. Adding a fee on the removal of stables from any PSM, however, is inappropriate, and represents a major reversal of one of the most consistent policies MakerDAO governance has had around the sanctity of peg management. If GUSD is meant to be escrowed away from the market to realize yield, that is entirely acceptable, but should be done so by either re-branding the GUSD PSM as a GUSD vault or some other means. Adding capital controls to any PSM directly contradicts the very name of the facility – Peg Stability Module – and the two concepts of yield generation and liquidity management should not generally be commingled. End DAI Funding For SourceCred Summary: This proposal would discontinue SourceCred compensation after October 2022. Recommendation: Vote No. SourceCred has been credited with being the initial nudge that brought many prominent community members into the DAO from social media. It has a strong potential to convert casual members of the community into contributing members. While we recognize that forum discourse has deteriorated in the last several quarters, we would prefer to see GovAlpha seek a mandate to use more discretion in setting parameters for SourceCred, gating its access, or rolling out more substitutes (like off-chain bounties) than ending the program entirely. Remove ETH Supply Yield and Liquidity Incentives from D3M Target Borrow Rate Calculations Summary: This proposal would remove LM and yield as part of the calculations of Maker D3M utilization. Recommendation: Vote Abstain. GFX Labs is involved with Interest Protocol, a competitor to Aave, the only deployed D3m at present. Allowed Spread Between D3M Borrow Rate and ETH-A Stability Fee Summary: This proposal would alter the allowed spread between targeted D3M borrow rate (bar parameter) and the ETH-A Stability Fee. Option 1 - 0.5% - implies bar of 2%, 90 million DAI exposure at 30% real supply cap, 680,000 DAI annual revenue. Option 2 - 0% - implies bar of 1.5%, 105 million DAI exposure at 30% real supply cap, 730,000 DAI annual revenue. Option 3 - Reject Options. NB: This is a ranked choice poll. Recommendation: Abstain. GFX Labs is involved with Interest Protocol, a competitor to Aave, the only deployed D3M at present. 1 Poll Ending October 17, 2022 Greenlight Poll: ANCHORAGE Summary: This poll asks whether the asset ANCHORAGE (Anchorage Lending Crypto Mining) should be prioritized for inclusion in the Maker Protocol. Recommendation: Vote No. Maker currently has no operational Real World Finance Core Unit, and simply cannot at present perform due diligence required.
As per standard policy, GFX Labs supported the current executive, which includes changes to parameters and some DAI disbursements that had already been approved by governance.

9 Polls Ending October 24, 2022 End Game MIP Set Summary: This MIP set includes MIP83, MIP84, MIP1c4-SP1, MIP4c4-SP1, MIP4c2-SP27, MIP39c2-SP35, MIP39c2-SP36, MIP39c2-SP37. Given the lengthy nature of discussions around the End Game and the voluminous material available to summarize, we will simply point curious readers to LongForWisdom’s summaries as a starting point, which can be found here. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This represents the largest package of reforms to MakerDAO governance ever proposed. As would be expected with a large number of concepts that interact with each other, there is something in this package for everyone to like and dislike. On balance, we feel these reforms are a positive step forward, and represent a return to MakerDAO turning its attention to the Maker Protocol, while offloading legal, microeconomic, and specialized tasks to the metaDAOs. We look forward to offering assistance in resolving some of the implementation details that are still to be mapped out, and doing what we can to make this new initiative successful. Offboarding Strategic Happiness (SH-001) Summary: This proposal would offboard SH-001, and provide 43,332 DAI and 26.04 MKR as offboarding relief to the facilitator. Recommendation: Vote Yes. MakerDAO is currently constrained by budget, and this Core Unit provides non-essential services that can no longer be supported financially. Offboarding Events (EVENTS-001) Summary: This proposal would offboard EVENTS-001, and provide 88,332 DAI as offboarding relief to its two contributors. Recommendation: Vote Yes. MakerDAO is currently constrained by budget, and this Core Unit provides non-essential services that can no longer be supported financially. Offboarding Real World Finance (RWF-001) Summary: This proposal would offboard RWF-001, and provide up to 60,000 DAI and 201.46 MKR as offboarding relief to its facilitator and two former contributors. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This Core Unit has been non-operational since the end of July, yet the facilitator has continued to draw around 100,000 DAI per month for expenses while no publicly visible work has been completed. The outgoing facilitator has insinuated he would pursue legal action against several parties if he were not continued to be paid. Providing him continued support during offboarding is distasteful, but will hopefully put an end to the long, drawn-out affair. It is time to move on from the mixed legacy left by this Core Unit, even if it requires payment to do so. MIP81: Coinbase Institutional Rewards Summary: This proposal would authorize use of Coinbase’s custodial services, which would pay between 100 and 150 bps on USDC deposited therein. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Concerns over whether USDC would in fact be retrievable at will from Coinbase can be alleviated by technical solutions. The yield on this is not particularly compelling, but Coinbase is an acceptable parking place for funds that are otherwise idle and earning zero yield. They should be retrieved when needed for the PSM or for a better-yielding opportunity, which makes this likely to be utilized for only a short period of time. MIP82: Monetalis Coinbase-Apaloosa Summary: This proposal would provide 500,000,000 DAI to Monetalis, which would then lend to Coinbase against ETH and BTC collateral. Yield from Coinbase to Monetalis is estimated to be between 150 and 300 bps, with a majority portion of that then going to Maker. Final terms would be subject to a poll before executing. Recommendation: Vote Abstain. Monetalis already holds authorization for a 500,000,000 vault for Monetalis Clydesdale. Assuming that vault is utilized to capacity, it is difficult to be enthusiastic about increasing the already concentrated counterparty risk this and two other proposed Monetalis deals would bring without first growing DAI supply. There may be room for more collaboration with Monetalis, but any additional deals such as Apaloosa, Freisian, or Andalusian would provide larger counterparty exposure to Monetalis – a new firm that has to date only deployed 1,000,000 DAI – than to Paxos (through the USDP PSM). We would prefer to see no single counterparty responsible for more than 10% of DAI in existence or 25% of stablecoin reserves. MIP55c3-SP9: Legal and Commercial Risk Domain Work for BlockTower Summary: This proposal earmarks 258,000 DAI to pay for an estimated three months of legal and risk domain work to evaluate the greenlit proposal from BlockTower. Two specific individuals have been named to perform this work. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The BlockTower proposal was greenlit, so someone is required to do the work that should have been performed or funded by the Real World Finance Core Unit, which has continued to draw funds but has not met its obligations under its mandate. The two contributors named to do this work previously performed similar work under the RWF-001 CU. MIP41c5 Amendments Summary: This subproposal would alter language and add detail around how facilitators are offboarded. Recommendation: Vote Yes. There will likely still need to be further iterations on this process, but clearly separating the process for offboarding a facilitator from that of a Core Unit seems appropriate. This amendment describes how powers are bounded during an unwinding process and also shortens the RFC period for facilitator offboardings. Quicker resolution (in either direction) of a facilitator offboarding is probably good, and perhaps even less than the 2 weeks in this amendment would be acceptable, since any facilitator offboarding involuntarily likely stems from high profile incidents. Facilitator Offboarding: RWF-001 Summary: This proposal would offboard the facilitator of RWF-001. NB: This proposal is separate from the RWF-001 Core Unit offboarding and provides no offboarding relief payment to the facilitator. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This facilitator has continued to draw pay while actively neglecting the mandate his CU was charged with since the end of July 2022.
As per our usual policy, GFX Labs has supported the current executive, which contains parameter changes and further utilization of the GUSD PSM and Monetalis Clydesdale vault.
In preparation for the upcoming expiry of GFX Labs’ original delegate contract, GFX Labs has begun migrating to a new delegate contract, which can be found here.

1 Poll Ending October 27, 2022 MIP65 Reallocation Summary: This proposal would alter the allocation previously selected to implement MIP65. 250,000,000 DAI previously earmarked to be invested into medium-term government and corporate bonds would instead be earmarked for a Blackrock 0-1 year US Treasuries ETF (fund details here). Recommendation: Vote Yes. Given the higher yields now available on US debt, coupled with the high probability of continued rate increases, this seems a reasonable adjustment to the previously approved allocation strategy.

3 Polls Ending November 3, 2022 Activate Liquidations on Stablecoin Vaults to Clear Bad Debt Summary: This proposal would turn on liquidations for vaults in the following ilks: GUSD-A USDC-A PAXUSD-A Recommendation: Vote Yes. These are vestigial ilks that pre-date the advent of Peg Stability Modules, where users could generate DAI against GUSD, USDC, or USDP. Over time, accrued fees have reduced many of these vaults below the collateralization threshold to avoid liquidations, but liquidations have not been enabled. By allowing liquidations, this will clear the protocol of “phantom DAI” that accrued from stability fees on these abandoned vaults. It is estimated that there is around 1.3m DAI in bad debt, mainly from these three ilks. There may also be some additional costs associated with auctioning off that bad debt. Fees have been disabled and all three stablecoins are hard coded to $1 value, so any remaining vaults in these ilks should avoid further liquidation. One Month Budget Extension for Strategic Happiness Core Unit Summary: This proposal would provide 5.21 MKR and 49,999.99 DAI for the former Strategic Happines CU to continue operations for one month. Recommendation: Vote No. This core unit was offboarded to reduce expenses. Maker Open Market Committee Proposal Summary: This proposal would: Reduce the MANA-A Maximum Debt Ceiling (line) from 17 million DAI to 10 million DAI. Increase the MANA-A Stability Fee from 4.5% to 7.5%. Onboard Compound V2 D3M with a Maximum Debt Ceiling (line) of 160 million DAI. Onboard Compound V2 D3M with a Target Available Debt (gap) of 10 million DAI. Onboard Compound V2 D3M with a Target Borrow Rate (bar) of 2%. Recommendation: Vote Yes. GFX Labs first proposed a D3M for Compound in December 2021. We fully support the implementation after nearly a year of work. The changes to MANA are recommended by Risk, and we agree with their recommendation. As per usual policy, GFX Labs supported the current and previous executives, which included previously authorized changes and disbursements. Please click through for details of the spell contents.

1 Poll Ending November 10, 2022 Compound V2 DAI D3M Summary: This proposal would initialize a Compound V2 D3M with a debt ceiling of 5,000,000 DAI and target borrow rate of 2%. Recommendation: Vote Yes. GFX Labs first proposed this nearly a year ago. We are excited to see this become reality. As per usual policy, GFX Labs supported the current executive, which included delegate compensation, some parameter changes, and technical deployment of Maker Teleport to StarkNet.

1 Poll Ending November 17, 2022 Stablecoin Vault Liquidation Parameters Summary: This proposal would alter the following parameters: Enable Liquidations. Use Linear Decrease for Auction Price Function (calc). Set Liquidation Penalty (chop) to 0. Set Proportional Kick Incentive (chip) to 0. Set Flat Kick Incentive (tip) to 0. Set Auction Price Multiplier (buf) to 1. Set tau to 4,320,000 seconds (72,000 minutes, or 1,200 hours). This results in an estimated 10bps drop in price every 72 minutes, or 50 days until the price reaches 0. Set Max Auction Duration (tail) to 43,200 secpnds (720 minutes, or 12 hours). This implies a minimum price of 0.99. Set Max Auction Drawdown (cusp) to 0.99. Individually set the Local Liquidation Limit (ilk.hole) for the vault types as follows: USDC-A - 20 million DAI USDP-A - 3 million DAI GUSD-A - 300,000 DAI Recommendation: Vote Yes. These are vestigial stablecoin ilks that pre-date the Peg Stability Module. While inflows are not allowed, there is still substantial debt accrued to vaults in these ilks. Enabling liquidations will clear the system of bad debt on several of these. NB: GFX Labs missed the deadline to vote on this poll, but this communication was prepared ahead of time and indicates how we would have voted had we done so. 13 Polls Ending November 28, 2022 Immunefi Security Facilitator Onboarding Summary: This proposal would onboard Joshua Pritikin (aka Psychonaut) as co-facilitator of the IS-001 CU. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This facilitator onboarding has failed in the past, and we are not aware of anything that has changed. That being said, Pritikin is clearly performing all facilitator duties for this core unit, and the current facilitator is not involved or even drawing a salary as far as we are aware. This represents a title change and addition of mandated actor status only. Budget Modification: DUX-001 Summary: This proposal establishes the next budget for DUX-001. Options are: Option 0: Abstain. Option 1: Approve existing budget only (Business as usual): 1,871,300 DAI Option 2: Approve reduced budget (NewBase): 1,611,420 DAI Option 3: Approve reduced budget (NewBear): 1,426,416 DAI Option 4: Reject budget. NB: This is a ranked choice poll. Recommendation: Vote Option 2 (NewBase), Option 3 (NewBear), Option 1 (Business as usual). The Development and UX Core Unit has generally done a good job maintaining the voting portal and working on some future initiatives for the launch of metaDAOs. That said, budget is a binding constraint for MakerDAO. Option 2 represents ~14% budget reduction, which is acceptable. MIP86: CoinShares Active Treasury Management Summary: This proposal would onboard CoinShares to manage a portfolio of 100,000,000-500,000,000 DAI with an aim to construct a portfolio of bonds that are relatively liquid, interest rate insensitive, and with a return above SOFR. Recommendation: Vote Abstain. While adding yet another name to the list of counterparties that could create an insolvent Maker in a black swan event is not a positive, the diversification away from highly concentrated counterparties is almost enough to offset that concern. The relatively conservative mandate laid out in MIP86 combined with governance selecting the exposure without needing a new MIP mitigates in our mind some risks. Keeping this deal on par with that of HVBC seems very appropriate, and is not so far from the existing Surplus Buffer that Maker would have no chance of surviving the unlikely event of the investment going to zero with no recovery at all. That being said, however, Maker currently has no clear oversight or monitoring of most RWA counterparties or their collateral. This needs to be clearly remedied, and immediately. Relatedly, CoinShares’ apparent misfortune of having what appears to be 10% of assets stranded at FTX suggests that this proposal needs to be tabled and revisited at a later date. We are conceptually supportive, but in light of current market conditions and Maker’s unclear financial position in a fast-paced environment, we would like more time and for the DAO to direct resources to due diligence. MIP87: OUSD Decentralized Rewards Summary: This proposal would authorize the deployment of up to 100,000,000 DAI into OUSD, which deploys DAI, USDC, and USDT for yield farming as a means of creating daily yield for OUSD holders. Recommendation: Vote No. Maker’s Risk Core Unit contributors have vehemently provided a negative recommendation. Many of their concerns can be found here, complete with details. We generally require a high bar to override a negative recommendation from the Risk Core Unit, and so will vote No. Modify Immunefi Security (IS-001) Mandate Summary: This proposal would alter the IS-001 mandate from the original to the proposed text (both found at links). Recommendation: Vote Yes. The new text largely elaborates upon the original in more detail, and explicitly places the MIP64 bug bounty program under the purview of IS-001. Budget Modification: IS-001 Summary: This proposal establishes the next annual budget for IS-001: Option 0: Abstain. Option 1: Approve existing budget (Business as usual): 786,830 DAI. Option 2: Approve reduced budget (BearMarket): 427,790 DAI. Option 3: Reject budget. NB: This is a ranked choice poll. Recommendation: Vote Option 2 (BearMarket), Option 3 (Reject Budget). This core unit largely administers the bug bounty program, incident response assistance, and educational resources for security. The lower budget seems adequate given that bug bounty payments are already authorized to come from general protocol resources as they occur under MIP64. Budget Modification: COM-001 Summary: This proposal establishes the next biannual budget for COM-001, which would be 258,807 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This core unit budget already reflects significant reductions, which should be rewarded. Budget Modification: SAS-001 Summary: This proposal establishes the next budget for SAS-001: Option 1: Approve new base budget: 433,375 DAI seed transfer and 1,040,100 DAI streamed over twelve months. Option 2: Approve new bear budget: 394,562.50 DAI seed transfer and 946,950 DAI streamed over twelve months. Option 3: Reject budget. Recommendation: Vote Option 3 (Reject Budget). This CU focuses on building out a unified interface for various auctions. After a year, it’s not clear that these tools see much use. Given the budget constraints for MakerDAO, this doesn’t seem like a prudent use of resources going forward. If a drastically reduced budget was proposed, perhaps that would be appropriate. Alternatively, it may be time to discuss offboarding and appropriate winding down packages for the contributors, particularly if consistent use of these tools cannot be demonstrated. Budget Modification: TECH-001 Summary: This proposal establishes the next annual budget for TECH-001, which would be 3,148,685 DAI in total. Recommendation: Vote No. The most mission-critical responsibility under the TechOps CU mandate is the maintenance of keepers to perform various (non-liquidation) functions in the protocol. TechOps is no longer the sole keeper for these functions, as Keep3r Network, Gelato, and Chainlink are also performing these duties. While maintenance of forum, website, Discord, and monitoring/alerts are important, a total spend of greater than 3 million DAI seems far too much – as reference, this is greater than the annual budget for Collateral Engineering Services CU, Growth CU, or Risk CU. Modify Emulated Surplus Buffer Upper Limit Summary: This proposal would set the upper bound for the MIP84 emulated surplus buffer to 1,000,000,000 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Abstain. The practical effect of this change would be to indefinitely delay the POVE (using protocol funds to invest in stETH) until the upper limit is reduced. This generally seems advisable in the current market environment. There has not, however, been an initiation of the POVE despite its authorization, and would prefer to revisit the appropriate buffer limit at initiation, so as to better reflect the reality of conditions at that time. MIP88: Monetalis-Redwood Freisian Summary: This proposal would authorize a vault for Monetalis to draw 225,000,000 DAI to purchase RMBS. Recommendation: Vote Abstain. Monetalis already holds authorization for a total of 1,000,000,000 DAI for Monetalis Clydesdale and Apaloosa. Assuming those vaults are utilized to capacity, it is difficult to be enthusiastic about increasing the already concentrated counterparty risk this would bring without first growing DAI supply dramatically. There may be room for more collaboration with Monetalis, but any additional deals such as Freisian or Andalusian would provide even larger counterparty exposure to Monetalis – a new firm that has not yet been given an opportunity to establish a track record. We would prefer to see no single counterparty responsible for more than 10% of DAI in existence or 25% of stablecoin reserves. MIP89: Monetalis-Arrow Andalusian Summary: This proposal would authorize a vault for Monetalis to draw 300,000,000 DAI to purchase ETF products backed by “green” lending and investments. Recommendation: Vote Abstain. Monetalis already holds authorization for a total of 1,000,000,000 DAI for Monetalis Clydesdale and Apaloosa. Assuming those vaults are utilized to capacity, it is difficult to be enthusiastic about increasing the already concentrated counterparty risk this would bring without first growing DAI supply dramatically. There may be room for more collaboration with Monetalis, but any additional deals such as Freisian or Andalusian would provide even larger counterparty exposure to Monetalis – a new firm that has not yet been given an opportunity to establish a track record. We would prefer to see no single counterparty responsible for more than 10% of DAI in existence or 25% of stablecoin reserves. Budget Modification: SES-001 Summary: This proposal establishes the next budget for SES-001: Option 1: Approve standard option budget: 2,719,200 DAI streamed over twelve months. Option 2: Approve speedy operations platform option budget: 3,199,200 DAI streamed over twelve months. Option 3: Reject budget. Recommendation: Vote Option 1 (Standard), Option 3 (Reject Budget). There is no demonstrated need for a higher budget. An option for a slightly lower budget would have been preferred, but not strongly enough to reject this budget outright. As is GFX Labs policy, we have supported the current and previous executives, which included changes already approved by governance and discussed individually in each poll upthread.

4 Polls Ending November 24, 2022 Add GNO As New Vault Type Summary: This proposal would add a GNO ilk with 2.5% stability fee and 5,000,000 DAI debt ceiling and 350% liquidation threshold. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This token has low liquidity, and slippage begins around 500,000 according to 1inch. However, with a LTV of around 23%, the protocol should be able to avoid losses through conservative support for GNO. Maker’s supported collaterals have dwindled over the last year. It’s worth experimenting with GNO. Add Multiple BlockTower Credit Vault Types Summary: This proposal would add four vaults for BlockTower Credit with debt ceilings of 20,000,000 DAI, 30,000,000 DAI, 30,000,000 DAI, and 70,000,000 DAI. All would have 4% stability fee. These vaults would be utilized to finance: Senior-secured, asset-backed facilities Forward Flow Agreements Whole loans and receivable purchases Structured Credit Products: Investment grade asset-backed securities (bonds) Recommendation: Vote Yes. To be perfectly frank, this is not a stellar deal for Maker. The assets are not cross-collateralized and there is no cash flowing directly to Maker on a regular timetable (NB: flows to the Tinlake platform are not identical to cash flowing to the Maker protocol, since that represents appreciation if the cash stays at Tinlake or other off-Maker reserves, or a revolving of the credit line if it is reinvested). Much like traditional permissionless vaults, this means the protocol’s exposure grows over time due to the accumulation of fees unless the borrower chooses to repay vault debt prior to closing the position or liquidation. The 4% yield is also not especially compelling given the time period of up to 48 months. The risk-free rate for 1 year is currently hovering around 4.7% and 4-year around 4.25%. Given the lengthy credit chain between Maker and the underlying assets, this is obviously not a risk-free investment. With that being said, the levels of junior capital offered by BlockTower suggest this is unlikely to be a dangerous deal for Maker on a financial basis. This proposal also marks a departure from some previous large-scale vaults where de minimis junior capital is present and yields even lower. As a result, this offering represents an upgrade in terms for Maker, even if the terms do not garner our enthusiastic endorsement. We should also note that there have been two different core units (two different engineering CUs) that have highlighted the technical risk of how this is being structured. Given that Maker is participating directly in these offerings, the technical risk and complexity by intermediating Centrifuge is not desirable. We strongly believe that Maker vaults should custody the actual tokenized collateral rather than a valueless dummy token. Particularly given Maker’s limited legal leverage in the event of unforeseen events, it seems strange to continue to custody the actual DROP tokens – which are the collateral for Maker’s purposes – at a third party. In summary, there are technical risks associated with this deal that we do not like and had hoped to see remedied after a year and a half of collaboration with various Centrifuge projects, and the financial returns seem very low. Compared to alternative opportunities, however, BlockTower is on balance offering an arrangement that is an improvement over previous ones, and so we vote yes. Offboarding Parameters for renBTC-A Summary: This proposal completes the offboarding of renBTC-A. This is being done as an expedited offboarding under MIP62. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Given uncertainty around Ren in the wake of Alameda’s bankruptcy, as well as the parallel deployment of Ren V2 while V1 is being deprecated (mints already disabled), it is appropriate to expedite this offboarding in case the peg for this asset becomes unstable. Total debt is less than 1,000,000 DAI. Proceed With Pre-Implementation Work For BlockTower’s MIP90 Summary: This proposal asks if core units should proceed with legal, credit, technical risk analysis of MIP90. MIP90 is not scheduled to be voted upon in January 2023. Recommendation: Vote Abstain. This proposal asks for no additional funding and seeks approval for something already within the mandate of core units. It is unnecessary micromanagement, and core units should be free to proceed or not with such work as they choose until MIP90 is voted upon.

3 Polls Ending December 1, 2022 DAI Savings Rate Adjustment Summary: This proposal seeks to set a new DAI Savings Rate (DSR), with the following options: Leave the DAI Savings Rate unchanged at 0.01% Increase the DAI Savings Rate to 0.25% Increase the DAI Savings Rate to 0.5% Increase the DAI Savings Rate to 0.75% Increase the DAI Savings Rate to 1% NB: This is a ranked choice poll Recommendation: Vote Leave the DSR unchanged at .01%. The DSR may be appropriate to activate, but more information is required to make an informed decision. Firstly, it would be helpful to have an inventory of historical integrations, and how many of those are still maintained. Knowing this would help estimate the likelihood of uptake by DAI users. Secondly, Maker would need to begin monitoring its net interest rate margin, and someone needs to be explicitly tasked with that (our preference is @Risk-Core-Unit). On the surface, this appears like it could lead to adverse selection where Maker is effectively subsidizing Lido staked ETH – users borrow conservatively against it at 0% currently, and then get additional yield carrying the DAI. While from a user perspective this is already the case when they park their borrowed DAI on Compound/Aave, using the DSR then has Maker both holding the risk of the collateral and paying for the privilege to do so (rather than Aave/Compound DAI borrowers paying to do so). Risk under @Primoz has a history of tracking such nuances, and we feel they should be explicitly mandated to monitor these risks, volunteer to do so, or some new actor be tasked with that role. Thirdly, if Maker is finally ready to reactivate the DSR, we would prefer to take a slower approach and instruct @Growth-Core-Unit under @Nadia to leverage any coming raise in any way possible to secure or reactivate integrations. GFX Labs is supportive of a reactivated DSR, but feel any such changes can be safer and more useful with a plan. We encourage champions of DSR reactivation like @hexonaut and @monet-supply to continue to advocate for it as an execution strategy is built out over another few weeks. Open Market Committee Proposal Summary: This proposal would enact a variety of parameter changes, the most notable of which being increased maximum debt ceilings for stETH, and reduced ones for wBTC, ETH, and Gelato UNI ilks. It also sets MANA debt ceiling to 0, and increases the cap on the Compound D3M from 5,000,000 DAI to 10,000,000 DAI. A more detailed list of parameter adjustments proposed can be found here. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The changes proposed are all reasonable and the explanation for them by the committee was also reasonable. Undertake Necessary Risk and Legal Assessments to Increase NS-DROP Debt Ceiling to 50,000,000 DAI Summary: This proposal instructs the Strategic Finance CU to conduct legal and risk assessments required for an informed vote on whether to raise New Silver’s debt ceiling. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This needs to be completed prior to an informed vote, and New Silver – as the oldest non-stablecoin RWA supported by the protocol, and with a history of repayment – deserves a vote on their request to raise their debt ceiling (and fee).

As usual, GFX Labs supported the most recent executive, which included a number of minor housekeeping issues, as well as the long-awaited Compound D3M activation. GFX Labs first proposed the Compound D3M one year ago.

5 Polls Ending December 15, 2022 Change Ownership of Ambassador Program’s Multi-Sig Summary: This proposal would remove @kat from the Ambassador Program Multi-Sig and replace her with @Sebix. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Kat has communicated a desire to step back from this program. We wish her the best of luck with all her current and future endeavors. Dai Foundation Board Election Summary: MakerDAO may appoint one board seat for Dai Fonden. The choices are: Daimon-Law 0xbocaJ Abstain Neither NB: This is a ranked choice poll. Recommendation: Vote Neither. This is not a vote declaring both candidates unfit, but a recognition that more time is needed to evaluate the two candidates. In particular, Daimon-Law’s possible conflicts within the Avalanche ecosystem and CLO position at Pangolin Exchange, as well as 0xbocaJ’s role as advisor to Redwood Trust, which is an entity recently approved as an end borrower through a Monetalis initiative, both warrant more time and consideration. Sidestream Auction Services (SAS-001) Funding Request Summary: This proposal would authorize SAS CU to continue using its previous budget beyond its original end date. This would not result in the transfer of new funds. Recommendation: Vote No. Sidestream’s budget was recently rejected. We feel the core unit’s function is no longer needed, and would prefer to see a budget for unwinding or being absorbed by other core units. GovComms (COM-001) Funding Request Summary: This proposal would authorize COM-001 to continue using its previous budget beyond its original end date, with the intention of using those funds for orderly winding down. This would not result in the transfer of new funds. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is reasonable, and offboarding relief for contributors will be handled separately through the formal offboarding proposal that is currently in RFC. Ratification Poll For Pioneer DeFi-focused Language Dataset for the Benefit of Risk Modelling & Governance Communication Summary: This proposal would provide 50,000 DAI for a SPF to create a Large Language Model to inform risk parameters. Recommendation: Vote No. As we understand it, this SPF would fund the training of a model that would monitor sentiment in social media. In our opinion, that has no useful application in Maker’s current risk framework. As per GFX Labs usual policy, the most recent executive was supported, which included a wide array of disbursements, parameter changes, and RWA onboarding work. Details can be found at the executive.

3 Polls Closing January 12, 2023 Approve One-Time MKR Distribution To Correct For CES-001 Incentive Program Shortfall Summary: This proposal would transfer 96.15 MKR to the Collateral Engineering Services auditor wallet. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The details around accelerated vesting for outgoing contributors several months ago are still being worked out, but the interim head of CES needs this MKR to make good on promises to current contributors. Confirm Trial Deployment of DssKiln Summary: This proposal seeks to confirm the previously approved (in June 2022) DssKiln prior to deployment. Voters may choose: Yes; 0.5 million DAI Yes; 1 million DAI Yes; 2 million DAI Yes; 3 million DAI No, do not burn MKR NB: This is a ranked choice poll. Recommendation: Vote 3 million DAI, 2 million DAI, 1 million DAI. This was already approved for 3,000,000 DAI to purchase MKR to burn. There is no need to poll for it again. Open Market Committee Proposal Summary: This proposal includes a number of parameter changes: Increase wstETH-B Stability fee from 0% to 0.25% Increase fees into (tin) PSM-USDP from 0.1% to 0.2% Increase Compound D3M debt ceiling from 5,000,000 to 20,000,000 DAI Increase Aave D3M debt ceiling from 0 to 20,000,000 DAI Recommendation: Vote Yes. Discontinuing fee-free leverage on Lido staked ETH is long overdue. Additionally, increasing D3M activity onto the two largest DAI borrow/lend marketplaces offers much better risk reward than alternative growth avenues. Limiting inflows of USDP is also appropriate, given GUSD remits payment to Maker, and two illiquid fiat stablecoins are probably not needed. Over time, USDP will likely drain out of the PSM a little at a time. 8 of 15 Polls Ending January 23, 2023 Keeper Network Amendment (MIP4c2-SP31) Summary: This proposal provides minor improvements to MIP63, such as fixing typos and specifying a maximum of 6 months’ budget request. Recommendation: Vote Yes. These are iterative improvements. Nothing appears likely to cause a problem. Defense Fund Summary: This proposal would establish a special fund to reimburse Recognized Delegates, Core Unit contributors, and voting MKR holders for expenses related to legal or regulatory actions. 5,000,000 DAI would be used to seed the fund. Specifics of how this fund would operate are subject to a procedures manual that are under development by the companies Gallagher and Artex. This fund would not be applicable to any current or past litigation. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This provides a much-needed way for possible targets to be reimbursed for expenses related to litigation or enforcement actions. That being said, we expect a detailed presentation of the procedural manual once it is ready. We are also voting Yes with the understanding that this fund is only for reimbursement of expenses, and not damages awarded or fines. A fund that covered payouts to plaintiffs would likely attract nuisance lawsuits. MIP92: Onboard PSM USDC to Yearn Summary: This proposal would onboard 100,000,000 USDC to a custom Yearn strategy vault. Yearn takes a 20% performance fee at present. Recommendation: Vote No. The performance fee seems quite high, and most of the strategies currently are relatively simple, so Maker could implement them itself (and probably should). We would be open to a revised version of this proposal that 1) requests DAI rather than direct custody of PSM USDC, 2) lower performance fees, 3) posts YFI or other collateral to share in any downside and not only the upside. If @corn wants input on crafting a new proposal, GFX Labs is willing to provide that. Declaration of Intent: Develop a Comprehensive On-Chain Solution for Monitoring RWA Vaults Summary: This proposal requests within 30 days for external providers to craft Special Purpose Fund (SPF) proposals to monitor RWA vaults. All submitted SPFs would then be voted upon to determine a single winner or no winner for funding. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Maker has struggled to monitor RWA vaults, with no viable solutions being provided historically in the form of oracles or manual monitoring. Building automated solutions for any or all of the monitoring for the disparate RWA vaults is a priority to de-risk the RWA program. This proposal publicly solicits proposals from external actors and signals a willingness to fund them. At worst, no funds are disbursed if all proposals are a poor fit, or if no proposals are forthcoming. While Strategic Finance Core Unit has the current mandate to monitor RWAs, some of its staff are members of the Viridian Cluster, which is itself structured around onboarding RWAs. Having a monitoring solution that assists SF CU in its mandate, and doing so in an arm’s length way, would be closer to best practices. Keeper Network: Onboard Chainlink Automation Summary: This proposal would provide a budget of no more than 1,000 DAI/day to Chainlink for performance of keeper duties. Chainlink has performed ~9% of all keeper calls tracked in makerburn.com Recommendaiton: Vote Yes. The addition of Chainlink to Gelato, Keep3r Network, and Maker’s own keepers creates a comfortable amount of redundancy and assurance that keepers will call various permissionless functions in the Maker Protocol. Special Purpose Fund: Developing Proof-of-Performance for Viridian Cluster Summary: This proposal would provide 500,000 DAI for developing monitoring and due diligence for RWA projects that originated from MIP65, MIP81, and MIP88. Recommendation: Vote No. This proposal is brought forward by the facilitator from the Viridian Cluster. The cluster itself was proposed by the RWA originator that would be monitored. The Strategic Finance Core Unit’s RWA specialist, who is presumably catching up on the monitoring of RWAs already, is also a member of the Viridian Cluster. GFX agrees that better RWA monitoring is very necessary, but paying the Viridian Cluster to monitor its own assets is not using best practices. Maker requires its own monitoring of Viridian Cluster and its assets, not to pay the cluster to monitor itself. Special Purpose Fund: Commercial Risk and Legal Domain Work to Support SF-001 Expanded Mandate Related to RWA Summary: This proposal would provide 209,000 DAI for the purposes of paying a structured finance consultant and legal review of RWAs. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The existing SF-001 budget doesn’t account for a RWA mandate. No one else is currently doing this work. There’s little reason not to approve this request, as it is not the first – and likely not the last – such request. Protocol DAI Transfer: IS-001 Summary: This proposal would distribute 43,560 DAI to the Immunefi Core Unit. The core unit states they will likely dissolve/offboard in May when this budget is exhausted. The core unit’s previous budget was rejected. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Given the stated intent to wind down operations of the core unit and transition to an ecosystem actor (which does not receive a budget), this transfer is reasonable. In general, though, we do not like separating funding from mandates/authorization, which MIP14 transfers do. As per our usual policy, GFX Labs is supporting the current executive, which contains a variety of already-approved DAI and MKR funding transfers.

7 of 15 Polls Closing January 23, 2023 Protocol DAI Transfer: TECH-001 Summary: This proposal would distribute 138,894 DAI to the TechOps Core Unit. The core unit’s previous budget was rejected. Recommendation: Vote Yes. The core unit cannot put forth another budget until March, due to internal procedural constraints. GFX dislikes separating funds transfers from mandates and authorizations. That being said, we will not oppose this based purely on the dislike of MIP14 funds transfers. COM-001 Offboarding Summary: This proposal offboards the GovComms Core Unit. It provides several options for offboarding relief for the contributors. The core unit’s previous budget was rejected. Approve Offboarding, 60,700 DAI Golden Parachute and 80% Multiplier for retroactive MKR Approve Offboarding, 60,700 DAI Golden Parachute and 100% Multiplier for retroactive MKR Approve Offboarding, 60,700 DAI Golden Parachute and 120% Multiplier for retroactive MKR Reject Options Abstain NB: This is a ranked choice vote. Recommendation: Vote 80% multiplier for retroactive MKR, 100% multiplier, 120% multiplier. This core unit is being offboarded due to budgetary constraints and a reduced need for their services. They performed their duties satisfactorily during their tenure, and deserve offboarding relief. We wish them the best of luck in their future endeavors. Modify MIP14c4 (Protocol DAI Transfer Ceiling) Summary: This proposal would amend MIP14 to remove the 250,000 DAI maximum for a MIP14 transfer. Recommendation: Vote Abstain. GFX Labs would prefer for MIP14 to be retired and a new MIP authored. See our communication on that item for more details. Obsolete MIP Removal of MIPs 23 and 24 Summary: This proposal removes two obsolete MIPs, which no longer contain relevant information or authorizations related to the old Domain Team system under the Maker Foundation. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is just cleaning up the MIPs repository. MIP14 Repeal Summary: This proposal would remove MIP14, which has never seen an approved use to date. Recommendation: Vote Yes. MIP14 imposes arbitrary limits on DAI to be transferred, separates funding approval from authorization of the initiative to be funded, has no oversight mechanisms embedded in it, and can only authorize the transfer of DAI and not other tokens. Modify MIP51c4 (Calendar Exceptions) Summary: This proposal would amend MIP51 to remove the December exception to the monthly governance cycle. Recommendation: Vote No. Urgent matters can still be brought to governance, but having a predefined time for governance to slow down over major holidays (Christmas, New Year’s, et al) also provides time for technical contributors to know major demands from governance are unlikely to occur. Amend MIP61 To Tighten Up Recognized Delegate Compensation Metrics Summary: This proposal seeks to add up to two modifications to MIP61. The first is to add a penalty for delegates with a very large share of Abstain votes. The second is to add a requirement around timing of executive votes and weighting them more highly than standard polls. Approve both Approve only the Abstain Modifier Approve only the Higher Participation Requirements and Weighting for Executive Votes Abstain Reject both changes NB: This is a ranked choice poll. Recommendation: Vote Approve only the Abstain Modifier. The abstain modifier makes some sense, but there’s also the risk of people picking semi-random non-abstain options to avoid a penalty. We do not believe the change in weighting to executive votes is needed, nor an addition of a timing parameter when most delegates need time to review executable code, or refer it to those who can do it on their behalf. 2 Polls Ending January 19, 2023 Adjust GUSD-PSM Debt Ceiling Summary: This poll seeks to find out if Maker holders want to adjust the current maximum exposure of the GUSD-PSM. Abstain Set DC to 0 DAI Set DC to 100,000,000 DAI No Change (500,000,000 DAI) NB: This is a ranked choice vote. Recommendation: No Change (500,000,000 DAI). The first rewards have been delivered as scheduled. As long as the rewards continue, there is not an obvious reason to unwind this arrangement. Our understanding is that GUSD reserves are custodied at the same trio of banks as the USDP reserves (and TUSD as well), and that they are segregated and designed to be bankruptcy remote from Gemini. Given that no new information has become available to suggest otherwise, GFX Labs does not see a need to unwind this arrangement at this time, though it is certainly appropriate to periodically check with the MKR-holding community. Decrease GUSD tout fee to 0 Summary: This poll seeks to lower the fee on outflows from the GUSD-PSM to 0 from 0.1%. Recommendation: Vote No. The GUSD-PSM is a revenue-generating ilk for the Maker Protocol as long as Gemini maintains their marketing incentives program. There is no immediate reason to make it easier for that income to be reduced. For those who feel there is an urgent need to reduce GUSD exposure, neither this poll nor the other current one would actively remove GUSD from the protocol, which likely would require an incentive to accomplish quickly.

2 Polls Closing January 26, 2023 Offboarding Parameters for GUSD-A, USDC-A, and USDP-A Summary: This proposal sets parameters for these three ilks to force a liquidation of all vaults. Recommendation: Vote Yes. These are vestigial vault classes from several years ago, before the Peg Stability Module was created. These vaults appear to be abandoned, and communications will continue to be ongoing in an attempt to get any affected users to withdraw their stablecoins, which were used as collateral to generate DAI. Adjust The Debt Floor (dust parameter) Summary: This proposal seeks approval to alter the dust parameter for several ilks. Voters may choose from: Option 1 - Broad Reduction Reduce dust for ETH-A, WBTC-A, and WSTETH-A to 5,000 DAI Reduce dust for ETH-C, WBTC-C, and WSTETH-B to 2,500 DAI Reduce dust for ETH-B and WBTC-B to 15,000 DAI Reduce dust for CRVV1ETHSTETH-A, LINK-A, YFI-A, and MATIC-A to 10,000 DAI Option 2 - Limited Reduction Reduce dust for ETH-A, WBTC-A, and WSTETH-A to 7,500 DAI Reduce dust for ETH-C, WBTC-C, and WSTETH-B to 3,500 DAI Reduce dust for ETH-B and WBTC-B to 25,000 DAI No Change Keep dust unchanged across all collateral types NB: This is a ranked choice vote. Recommendation: Vote Option 2, No Change. A limited reduction seems appropriate given the lower gas environment. We would prefer to see whether a limited reduction brings in more diverse users of the Maker protocol software before aggressively exposing Maker to the risk of small vaults becoming unprofitable to liquidate, should high gas prices return. We also want to be cautious about going too far and needing to then reverse the decision, as that makes for a bad user experience – once a user is below the dust limit, they can no longer repay only a portion of their user-generated DAI.
