As is our usual policy, GFX Labs is supporting the current executive, which includes a number of parameter changes, technical housekeeping, and disbursements.

1 Poll Ending February 2, 2023 Protocol DAI Transfer To Fund Endgame Information Portal Summary: This proposal would transfer 9,999 DAI to an address TBD. The stated use of these funds is to utilize a JokeDAO contest to offer a bounty to a winning proposal to create an information portal with various resources about the ongoing Endgame initiatives. Recommendation: Vote No. This should be a Special Purpose Fund under MIP55, since it involves deliverables and is not simply a transfer of funds. Strictly speaking, this is a proposal to send 9,999 DAI to an address that has not been specified, and with no formal or informal obligations by either those administering the JokeDAO contest, nor any recipients of the grant/bounty. The cost and concept are fine, but this proposal should utilize best practices. Were it anyone other than two well-known, large delegates, there would be no chance of authorizing a blind transfer of 10k DAI to an unspecified address.
As is our usual policy, GFX Labs supported the current executive, which includes some technical work around the Maker Teleport program and DAI transfers to support ongoing work by Strategic Finance.

2 Polls Closing Thursday February 9, 2023 Update Multisig Managing Velodrome NFT Summary: This proposal would remove MakerMan, who is retiring from the obligation, and add CodeKnight and Stablenode to the multisig on Optimism that manages the Velodrome NFT. The multisig would become a 3 of 5 (it is currently a 3 of 4). Recommendation: Vote Yes. Removing a retired delegate and adding two current ones seems appropriate. Open Market Committee Proposal Summary: This proposal would alter a variety of parameters. Notable changes would reduce fees on several ilks and reactivate the Aave V2 D3M with a debt ceiling of 20,000,000 DAI. Fees would also be increased by 25bps on wstETH-B and the Compound D3M increased by 10,000,000 DAI to a toal of 30,000,000. For a full list of all parameter changes proposed, please check the original thread  Recommendation: Vote Yes. The parameters recommended by the committee are all reasonable. As per our usual policy, GFX Labs is supporting the current executive, which contains changes to dust parameters, delegate compensation, and initiation of a payment stream to Chainlink for keeper services.

1 Poll Ending February 16, 2023 Restart a $100 Micro-Burn of MKR in Show of Good Faith to MKR Holders Summary: This proposal would authorize 36,400 DAI for a weekly burn of 700 DAI, implemented via DssKiln Recommendation: Vote Yes. This will be an acceptable test of DssKiln in the wild. Additionally, it may reassure MKR holders in an environment where significant immediate and annual dilution is being proposed through the End Game. 4 Polls Ending February 27, 2023 Declaration of Intent: Implement a Feature to Refund People Who Lost Money Sending DAI to the DAI Contract Address Summary: This proposal states that a feature should be implemented in the future to make whole users who mistakenly sent DAI to the token address. Recommendation: Vote Yes. GFX has long been an advocate of better protections for small holders, and are pleased to see this issue raised again. Note that a Declaration of Intent does not by itself commit Maker to any specific course of action. Amend MIP62 to Allow Changing Communication Responsibilities Summary: This amendment would 1) remove references to GovComms CU in the collateral offboarding communications process, as that CU is no longer active, and 2) allow for future substitutions under MIP62 provided the named party is unwilling or unable, and a willing member of the community is ready to assume those communication tasks. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This is simply common-sense cleanup of MIP62. Amend MIP41: Interim Facilitator Appointment Process Summary: This amendment would make various changes to improve the process to appoint interim facilitators. Examples include election by core unit vs by facilitator, since some CUs have multiple facilitators, and a path for a facilitator during a voluntary offboarding to appoint a single successor. Recommendation: Vote Yes. These changes are largely in response to edge cases identified during the recent CES-001 interim facilitator appointment. Most seem like obvious improvements to the process. MIP95: $100,000,000 of Cogent Bank Loan Participations Summary: This proposal would approve 100,000,000 DAI for loan participations alongside a portfolio originated by Cogent Bank. This deal is substantively the same structure and terms as the Huntingdon Valley Bancorp (which is in the process of being acquired by Citizens Financial Services, Inc.) Recommendation: Vote Yes. Generally, we are wary of MakerDAO approving new collaterals that touch the real world markets while the DAO is undergoing the intense levels of uncertainty and internal instability while responds to the End Game proposals. We also would like to see a shift towards Maker holding senior tranches of these portfolios, instead of participating pari passu on a 50/50 basis, and at lower levels than $100,000,000 while Maker’s cash reserves are less than that amount. That being said, there are thousands of community banks in the United States. They represent a market that is hungry to access affordable capital from Maker, and can scale rapidly as a result, giving the DAO granularity and diversification in its combined underlying portfolio. Politically, a narrative of Main Street businesses and jobs being financed by DeFi is also deeply appealing. In the current environment, Maker needs friends, and helping community banks – which are often starved of capital readily available to larger, politically connected banking institutions – serve the needs of their local communities is one way to do that. It is, quite frankly, a way to make good by doing good. As a result, GFX votes Yes on this proposal, and hopes to see many more that are similar in the future – though we expect to see iterative improvements going forward, rather than copying the HVBC proposal, which was partly a proof of concept.

2 Polls Closing February 23, 2023 Audit and Review Work For Phoenix Labs Summary: This poll seeks to clarify if MKR holders desire Protocol Engineering CU to review and procure audits for Spark Protocol (which has three proposals likely to be voted upon in March). Recommendation: Vote No. If Spark Protocol is passed in March, then we do not expect this vote to be construed as opposition to the standard technical review, but do not support Spark receiving special prioritization or extraordinary resources. Engineering Resource For Phoenix Labs Summary: This poll seeks to clarify if MKR holders desire Protocol Engineering CU to divert 1 full-time engineer to work for Phoenix Labs/Spark Protocol. Recommendation: Vote No. Protocol Engineering has a backlog of work on Maker’s multi-chain Teleport, as well as other responsibilities. Phoenix Labs should present a separate budget or increase its pending requests if it requires engineering resources. As per our usual policy, GFX Labs supported the current executive, which included parameter changes and Aave V2 D3M.

1 Poll Ending March 2, 2023 Open Market Committee Parameter Proposal Summary: This poll would alter a number of parameters. Among the proposed changes are: Increase the ETH-C Stability Fee by 0.25% from 0.5% to 0.75%. Increase the WSTETH-B Stability Fee by 0.25% from 0.5% to 0.75%. Increase the WBTC-C Stability Fee by 0.25% from 0.75% to 1%. Increase the YFI-A Stability Fee by 0.5% from 1% to 1.5%. Increase the RETH-A Maximum Debt Ceiling by 10 million DAI from 10 million DAI to 20 million DAI. Increase the YFI-A Maximum Debt Ceiling by 1 million DAI from 3 million DAI to 4 million DAI. Increase the Compound v2 D3M Maximum Debt Ceiling by 40 million DAI from 30 million DAI to 70 million DAI. Increase the Aave v2 D3M Maximum Debt Ceiling by 15 million DAI from 5 million DAI to 20 million DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Slowly raising rates and increasing debt ceilings is appropriate. In particular, we are very supportive of wstETH-B fee increases and higher exposure to the Compound and Aave D3Ms. NB to GovAlpha: GFX failed to vote in this poll, but this communication has still been provided.

2 Polls Closing March 9, 2023 MIP55c3-SP15: Phoenix Labs Initial Funding Summary: This proposal would create a Special Purpose Fund (SPF) of 50,000 DAI for Phoenix Labs to be formed as a legal entity in TBD jurisdiction and conduct legal research on what is required to launch a Spark Protocol front end. Recommendation: Vote Yes. Support for this SPF should not necessarily be construed as support for launching Spark Protocol or utilizing Phoenix Labs. The cost, however, is low, and it seems likely the legal research will be relevant even without Spark Protocol. Decrease RETH-A Dust Parameter Summary: This proposal would decrease the dust parameter for RETH-A vaults from 15,000 DAI to 7,500 DAI. Recommendation: Vote Yes. This change is recommended by the Risk Core Unit, and would harmonize RETH-A’s dust with similar vault classes. It was previously not included in reductions to other vault classes because RETH-A was newly live at the time.

As per usual policy, GFX Labs has supported the most recent executive spell. Its contents included sundry parameter changes, DAI disbursements, and MKR disbursements in accordance with previously approved polls.
GFX Labs supported the out-of-sequence executive spell that alters some parameters as a precaution amid current market conditions.

GFX Labs will NOT be supporting the out-of-sequence executive spell that would allow governance to instantly set PSM debt ceilings to 0. We feel that floating DAI needs to be behind a timelock delay for safety reasons, and a review of the only well-documented real-world example of a fixed currency suffering from its reference currency having problems is the unwinding of the Bretton Woods system in the 1970s. We worry that using the ability in presented in this spell would be irreversible, and should not be implemented quickly. We are, however, willing to reconsider our position on this topic given more time to think about its consequences and the proposal comes through standard governance processes.

I respect your position, and particularly the desire to slow down the pace of governance proposals and allow for more deliberation. I’m looking forward to the overall pace of activity moderating in the coming days so we can begin to think in more big-picture strategic terms. However, on balance I and my risk colleagues continue to believe the risk/reward of implementing this change now is highly favorable. Our general reasoning:  PSM Breaker is not quite analogous to end of Bretton Woods, as it is possible to deactivate just a single at-risk PSM while maintaining the DAI peg via the other PSMs (for example, over the weekend if we had the capability we could have deactivated just USDC, while leaving GUSD and USDP available to service DAI demand) Allowing continued minting via an at-risk PSM (as happened this weekend) can have the effect of making DAI free floating due to liquidity and solvency concerns, with a greater likelihood of DAI diverging from target price than if the PSM breaker is used promptly to address changing conditions Governance can remove this PSM breaker mechanism in the future if alternative risk mitigations are in place or if the risk/reward or voter preferences change  Just wanted to share our perspective here, but again we completely respect your decision on the matter and look forward to making further improvements and risk mitigations through a more deliberative governance process in the coming weeks.
